posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

>>9611264
Today I am officially starting /vr/'s first Serious Sam mapping project called "A Serious Case Of /vr/"
If you're new to mapping with SED1 then check out this quick start guide: https://rentry.org/vy4qr

A Serious Case of /vr/ Rules:
>Map must be made for Serious Sam The Second Encounter 1.07 version (this is the most up to date retail version on Steam/GOG)
>Usage of custom textures, sounds, and music is approved and encouraged
>Usage of custom entities or other mods is NOT allowed. Outside of textures, sounds, and music your map should be 100% vanilla with 1.07
>Please provide a readme listing your name (even if it's anonymous), map name, and sources for any custom content used
>Map must be beatable and have proper co-op support
>Do not make edits of existing maps
>Project host has the final say and can deny your entry if it is not up to /vr/ "standards" (please put some effort into your map)
>Rules are subject to change
>Deadline: TBD

Tips:
>Trigger a checkpoint whenever a new weapon is picked up to ensure everyone spawns with an up-to-date arsenal
>Make co-op portals for arenas that get closed off (and/or one-way doors so players don't get trapped)
>Aim to balance your map around Serious difficulty first, but don't be afraid to make support for other difficulties later
>Try to keep co-op in mind when balancing fights, drawn out reinforcement spawners are not fun to wait on
>Hot starts are not that common in Serious Sam, make a "lobby" for players to jump around in without risk of triggering anything (useful for co-op)
>A good fight is more enjoyable than a good looking room, don't stress yourself out over brushwork
>Use the official maps as references (I won't berate you for coping models, texture work, etc. from official maps) (You can have multiple maps open at the same time and switch between them on the fly in the editor)
>Don't forget to make a thumbnail for your level
>Ask questions if you need help
>Get creative with secrets!

Because the dev made basically made every wrong decision and the resulting game is simply not fun to play:
1. He spent great deal of time crunching numbers to ensure balance - but forgot to make gameplay actually fun
2. Focused on co-op multiplayer too much - even though it's not a Zandronum game
3. Giant, boring levels that you constantly have to go through
4. Couldn't keep it in his pants. Usually people are willing to overlook one weird fetish, but not two at once. If it was just bara men, or just furries, it would've been fine, but bara furries is over the line. The point of fanservice is to attract potential players, not to alienate them.

This game is extremely educational, it should be studied by any fledgling game designer, you can write long essays on what went wrong with it.

I decided to dig through the past few threads to get some numbers. Counting the amount of posts explicitly pertaining to SRB2K in each thread led me to these results
>25 posts of 527 last thread, about 4.7%
>20 posts of 588 before that, about 3.4%
>14 posts of 602 in the thread preceding that, about 2.3%
>Said posts are frequently about creating content (i.e. Sprites) for the game
>Said posts are also usually screenshots with little text content, doesn't take up much screen space
Going by the past three threads, SRB2K related content makes up less than 5% of posts in these threads. Said posts are so minimal that anyone not interested can easily scroll past them, even the long ones because 2000 characters is not a lot. That leaves the only argument being "it's not an FPS," but it is a mod of Doom, which is explicitly covered in the OP, reading
>Gameplay, WADs/Maps/Mods, Source Ports
(The game also has a first person view option, and you shoot people with various items, so there's that too)

In short, you're complaining about content that makes up a fraction of the threads, is easily avoidable, is infrequent to other games in comparison, harmless by 4chan standards, and is thread relevant.
Welcome to 4chan. If you don't like certain content, ignore it. If you think content is harmful, counteract it by posting content you like instead of complaining without substance.
tl;dr SRB2K is fun and on-topic, fuck off

That's equivalent to rolling a Nat 1 on a d20. I can see how some people would get butthurt about those odds, especially when it beats some unquestionably relevant series' representation, like Unreal, Heretic/Hexen, and even Serious Sam on an average day.
Of course, that can be blamed just as much on people not talking about those games as often as things like Doom, Quake, and even Blood or Duke3D (let alone SRB2K), but I still think it's valid to draw attention to SRB2K's possible overrepresentation.
Personally, I think that it being a Sonic fangame made in a retro Doom source port (assuming Doom Legacy is still the foundation of SRB2K; I wouldn't know to be honest) is reason enough to allow it. If SRB2 would be on-topic, SRB2K should be, too.

>>9614015
If anything, AI art will expose how "professional" art styles were always corporate and not as interesting
Art is a personal thing, so you can always draw for fun and not give a fuck if someone draws better than you
Not everything has to be a commission piece that floods Gelbooru or concept art for the next generic AAA RPG
Even with shit like "here's what you can do that AI art can't", most people already have a basic knowledge of art and culture is limited as is
You can add as many thought out details, easter eggs, characters, poses etc to a piece or a really unique character design and most people already prefer shit like "What if Pokemon WAS REALISTIC AND FOR ADULTS?"
But i always thought modern artists on Twitter were looking for excuses to procrastinate and complain about their art careers anyway
Doom wad generation is still limited as is and people thinking most custom wads are just slaughter wads will not take away the more interesting and unique wads away
All of this will make more sense when you realize people have basic knowledge on shit (partially because of the "crowded bus" internet monoculture) and that's why most websites, 4chan included, have similar vocabolary and memes instead of there being distinct website cutlures that you could understand why "redditor" or "tumblrette" were even used as labels anymore
Basically, "real media literacy" being knowing mroe shit and not copypasting the same conclusions that you clearly didn't copy from someone else
Even Doom is like this, whether it's Brutal Doom overshadowing most of modding or more people nowadays putting attention towards Isabelle crossovers

>>9614015
No it isn't, have you seen how much AI struggles with fundamentals? It can't even depict a hand or foot without completely fucking it up.
>"But look, AI has finally fixed hands!"
>hands are still absolutely fucked, missing joints, uneven segments, fingernails missing or melding into fingertips somehow, only difference is that it doesn't look like something else if you squint
>also the framing and composition is always the same as all the other images

AI lacks basically all the fundamentals of a brain, there's so incredibly much that goes into even a middling or poor artist to interpret and create their art, which AI has absolutely no other way of approaching but applying manually written instruction sets against high speed number crunching, the computer's primary strength. This is like cooking a steak with a blowdryer, it's so fundamentally unsuited for the task that it isn't even funny, and the increasing optimizations don't so much amount to increased heat output, rather just slightly improved airflow and power consumption.

You're pitting a century old technology which isn't even infinitely scalable like people think it is, against millions of years of evolution. The complete void of imagination, instinct, and abstract interpretation or deconstruction cripples it as an artist, it doesn't even UNDERSTAND what it looks at. Cutesexyrobutts tracing other artists results in better works than prompting an AI.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616709
>>9616714
It was fairly demanding, yeah, but you didn't have to spend $5000 on a machine to run it or anything. Mind, most people weren't even aiming to hit the peak 35fps at the time, a consistent ~20fps was considered very smooth, especially for a game like this (compare to Ultima Underworld, which ran FAR slower).
Depending on your hardware, and what you were fine with, you could knock down screen size a notch or two, or play on low detail mode, where the game still looked nuts by 1993 standards. If you were on the low end though, you could be in the situation where your computer simply didn't have the guts to run both Doom and drivers for your mouse at the same time, so it'd be keyboard only.

Hardware was also going down in price, as the market for PCs (partially driven by groundbreaking games such as Doom), developed at an insane pace in the 90s, so a pretty decent 486 computer which could get you an average 20fps with Doom 2 would be way down in price by the end of 1994, compared to how expensive it was the year before. Some older PCs could also be upgraded with new parts as well, including the processor, so you may not even need to shell out for a brand new machine to get better performance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616097
It's simple, really: Final Fantasy IV exists in a bizarro vacuum were there are no real "bad" versions of the game. The Super Famicom release? One of the earliest original versions that still holds up well. The PlayStation port? Surprisingly the best out of all the PlayStation conversions, they somehow really knocked the wait times way out of the park compared to the rest. The DS remake? Fixed handheld-constraint issues that plagued 3D Final Fantasy III. The PSP compilation? The most "complete" package and best localization overall, worst anyone can say is it don't look as good as previous PSP remakes. Even the censored/easy Super Nintendo release is still enjoyable. The only versions I'd say are outright bad are the cheap Wonderswan version -which goes to show just how bizarro-world this game really is- and the initial revision of the GBA version based on it. And maybe pixel remaster for braindead-regressing to a worse translation and casualizing a few aspects, but that's PR for you.
In short, Final Fantasy IV simply has more good options to choose from.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9619778
PSP expanded a few parts to fit more in line with TAY, like changing "Yang's Wife" to "Sheila" (which is a Japanese change too). Since that wasn't the goal of Pixel Remaster, they took the path of least resistance and based it on the more compatible GBA version, mildly tweaking a few parts. Similar reason why PSP was also a moderately tweaked GBA script instead of a heavily tweaked DS one - it requires less fuddling to fit in with the 2D versions. For that matter, most parts that PSP shared with DS is a consequence of TAY text being based on the at-the-time more recent DS script.
>The 2D version hasn't had a full new translation since PSX
It's maybe slightly less reworked than Final Fantasy VI on GBA, but I doubt you want to debate that it hasn't had a full new translation since SNES.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9615518
PAL Gamecube games run at 50hz, which means that they run 17% slower than NTSC 60hz games. A lot of PAL Gamecube games have the option to be ran at 60hz, but many don't.
I guess because the PAL games have a hz selection screen, they didn't include a 480i/480p selection screen, even though the hardware allows the games to run at 480p.
If you want to run your games at 480p, you need to make sure your Gamecube has a digital AV out port. Gamecubes made after Q2 2004 don't have this port. Your Gamecube will need to be connected to your TV by either component or an HDMI adapter, and you will need to use Swiss, which requires a boot disc (often wind waker or mario sunshine) and a memory card with Swiss and your game's exploit (ie: shinehax for mario sunshine) on it. You can make this memory card with a softmodded Wii with Gamecubee memory card slots. Alternatively, you could probably buy a premodded memory card online.
If you're playing on a CRT, you'll have to use the analogue AV out, which doesn't support 480p, in which case you can ignore basically all of that.

>>9615409
Hello OP, I have a pretty robust Gamecube collection I've been working on for years and wanted to give you a little general advice.

When it cones to starting a collection, there are a few things to consider. I think a collection is most appreciated when it represents the tastes and spirit of the collector. That being said, its possible for you or anyone else to get into Gamecube even with the recent high prices if you set your goals correct.

For instance, you may be be totally happy building a collection just consisting of Paper mario and 5 or 10 other games you really enjoy. Set a goal to get there. If you have more disposable income it makes it easier obviously but even if not you can collect it slowly over time. Start with Paper Mario, the game is up over 100 dollars now but if you keep an eye out you can probably snag it around 80 CIB and in good shape if you're willing to hunt around a few months. Also, maybe you have some other things you could sell towards that game. Games you own but don't really care for, some old guitar that's been sitting in your closet collecting dust for 10 years, whatever. Use the Marie Kondo method to find what sparks joy to get rid of and apply the same method to the games you build into your collection.

I had the fortune to collect some Gamecube games before the price jump but still finish my collecting during 2020 and 2021. Just collect slowly and thoughtfully and it will be a rewarding experience for you.

I've gotten into collecting for several consoles that people say its "too late" to collect for by this method and its been an enjoyable experience. Even after collecting those games its also been a good investment as the value has steadily risen compared to what I paid, which is cool- not that I'm planning to sell anything now. Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9618340
Phase Alternating Line. It's a colour encoding system for analogue televisions. It has more lines (higher resolution), but uses a lower frequency of electricity (lower refresh rate). The higher resolution doesn't really matter as far as gaming is concerned, as developers would generally ignore those extra lines and instead just use the NTSC picture, but with black bars above and below it.

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9618340
It stands for "Phase Alternating Line", as >>9618387 said. But it doesn't mean what he thinks it means. It has nothing to do with the number of lines. What it means is that the Phase of the v color difference component in the signal is Alternated every Line. This is part of what prevents it having the problem NTSC has with phase errors, which is why NTSC stand for Never The Same Color.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9618443
PAL is broadcast at 625 lines, while NTSC is broadcast at 525 lines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9618462
>PAL is broadcast at 625 lines
It's also "broadcast at" other lines. Because it's a color encoding system, not a broadcast system. Many people commonly, and incorrectly, use "PAL" instead of the correct terminology. This is fine for casual conversation, but when you're talking about what PAL actually means it's dead wrong. This makes it a great way to milk lols from the stead flow of uneducated children infesting /vr/.

Gen 2 has a great aesthetic, probably because it's simply building off Gen 1 but optimizing it for the GBC, making it very charming and pretty.

Still, I can't get behind the general praise for them as superior games. I don't think they're bad games, but they simply don't play as smoothly and seamlessly as an experience and there are many reasons for this, such as the day and night exclusive mons....an interesting gimmick that was impressive and immersive the first time you witnessed it as a child, but really puts a damper on things ultimately forcing you to schedule when you play or stop playing the game. Pokemon selection offers more Pokemon this time around yet it FEELS like there's less somehow, it's bizarre, it feels like a struggle to get a nice team going earlier on when you want to, Crystal "the favorite" even takes away your one option for the electric type, not to mention the lack of easily accessible stones means even some of the Pokemon you might choose won't evolve unless you happen to save the "right" phone numbers aka go look up a guide, or wait till endgame...and there's another thing, the second half of the game feels all out of wack, you reach the new Elite 4 too quickly, and the game after that point just feels kinda half assed, one of the few things everyone can agree was irritating about Gen 1, being forced to use unwanted HMs or resort to HM slaves is double downed on in Gen 2 adding multiple new HMs you never wanted ensuring you MUST have a HM slave this time and late game too, it's worse than cut and flash which you don't need once you get fly, there's just so many little things that make these games a bit rough

>>9614465
Most of my consoles use SCART RGB, so they go into a SCART switch->RGB to YPbPr->Component Switch->Scaler. The component switch has dual output so I run the other output to a PVM that accepts component video. The switches are all auto so I never need to press anything.
I have a few odd consoles that have native HDMI and those go into a HDMI switch (also auto). It's quite easy to manage with the right equipment. Everything is powered and ready to play through the same HDMI input, or simply turn on the CRT if you're using analog output.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616946
>Does anyone else find it bizarre how fucking expensive switchers are?
No, but I can understand how you would find it that way.
Like other posters said, there are some issues with quality assurance that increase the price, but that's unlikely to be the main issue.
>economy of scale
That's most likely the main issue.
It is a niche product. The are relatively few purchases of the product, which means production of the product has to remain low. Few places are producing the product and those places still have to dedicate time and resources to produce it. They have to set a price point which justifies production (and consumers' expectations).
Additional manufacturers could enter the market, but with the market being as lean as it is already every producer that engages in a short-term price war comes out a loser.
Then you have to factor in support. Support for a niche tech product.
Let's look at it from the opposite way:
>everybody poops
>lots of toilet paper needed
>lots of tp manufacturers
>fighting for shelf space/market
>cost incredibly low
>for product that's processed from sources that need years to mature
>into end result
>that billions of people deem acceptable enough to drag across their bare assholes
How much do you think it'd cost to turn trees into tactile clouds if only a few thousand people wiped their asses once every few years?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Played the demo that came with Official UK PSM. Utterly blown away, I immediately bought the game the second I saw it on a shelf.

Zero regrets, I played through the whole thing three times over, back to back.

The level of presentation and cinematography in MGS was in a league of its own at the time. It seriously stood out, and the fact that it was done with the in-game engine showed just what a collosal waste of time all of those pre-rendered videos we'd become used to had been.

The actual gameplay is pretty basic , but my god, what a polished experience the game was for 1998. There was nothing else on that level back then.

'Style over substance' could be a valid criticism, but stealth as a core gameplay mechanic was so rare to see back then that even MGS' simple implementation of it was perfectly fresh.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I noticed that mgs appealed to people that weren't typically into traditional games though not the way you'd think it being a movie game, more in it being a quasi dad game. I remember my brothers playing a few of the big 3rd and 4th gen platformers like super mario bros and dkc but mainly the games I remember them being into were driving, sports, a couple old flight sims, a couple fighting games, basically games where you were doing a recognizable activity instead of running through an abstract gauntlet. if mgs were a game where you just went room to room killing things rapid fire, boss fight, repeat my brothers would have had zero interest. however the slow adventure game like pacing, the optional codec calls, all the tech gimmicks and ways you could fuck with guards, this was very cool to them. Even my dad perked up once when he oversaw us messing around with a cardboard box. my brothers hated raiden in 2 but sticking up guards was something they could do for hours.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9618629
Laugh all you want at the melodrama and Kojimaisms but at the time, there had never been any mainstream game that excelled to that extent in terms of writing and voice acting and gameplay. FFVII had a great story and everyone loved the characters but there was a certain cartoonishness to it and everything was rendered purely in text on in pre-rendered cutscenes where no one spoke. Resident Evil was very cinematic but the "acting" was cheesy and amateurish. The Characters in MGS were the first, for a lot of people, where you felt like there was a genuine performance behind it, with actual voice acting like you'd find in an animated film and not just some guy reading off a cue card. It felt like an important threshold had been crossed. It was a benchmark for quality.

And it was also a good game that didn't play like anything else. Stealth was an underutilized mechanic so a game based around it seemed fresh and unique. It had memorable bosses, tons of cool gadgets, challenging but fair difficulty...it was just mild-blowing. Now I find it a little slow and limited but still very playable. At the time, I'd never seen anything like the total package this game offered. Zoomers will never understand the feel of fighting Psycho Mantis for the first time, being freaked out y him reading your memory card and having to figure out his gimmick. That kind of shit was unprecedented.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I believe there is one simple but very overlooked reason for why it's still so fun to pick up and even the best 3D platformer ever to many: rhythm.

There are many factors besides that, particuarly the level design, charm and open-endedness that allows for tackling levels and segments your own way, but its addictive rhythm is the thing almost no other game has and that's rarely talked about. For the most part, that means the moveset: You can constantly crank up the game's BPM (very much in accordance with the perfectly fitting soundtrack) and challenge yourself by timing triple jump, dives and other moves to fill the space that doesn't have enemies and platforming while still having to factor those into your timing if you don't want to mess up the rhythm. This may not apply to every level and the game has its low points, but it's precisely such low points that corroborate what I'm talking about. Even the easiest levels and platforming can be a challenge and involve risk and reward and pressing your luck in an addicivetly fun way.

Of course I'm by and large talking about Mario's moveset and what the levels allow you to do with it, which also includes things like doing backflips instead of standard jumps. Jak's moveset is one of the few similar ones I'm aware of, but even his rolls and long jumps don't really have the same rat-a-tat to them and feel more like spamming rolls in Zelda, besides being unfeasible or needlessly risky in narrow spots.

games were more fun back then because they required commitment

now if it doesn't feel perfectly accessible within the first few seconds it's dropped. Look at the mario parties and mario kart and how they control and see how much investment their sequels demand in comparison. In 64 take a basic mini game like lava tile isle, there is a unique sluggish acceleration to your movement in minigames, and in later entries it feels like a flash game in comparison. And imagine if MK64 had 12 player online. Do you think the item balance and course design would keep everyone together as it does in MK8? It would royally fuck over some people and leave them unable to even finish, I'm talking tumbling, red shelled out off the map, ghosts and lightning in first and second, larger skill gaps with players who can do consecutive drifts while making sure not to spin out just from wiggling the stick too much, weaving between trucks on toads turnpike. It's a joke in the remake. Gaming really is shit now, we had it good back then before 6th gen made us whine about everything

>is that a bad boxart? cause it makes me wanna research it and see what its about

average solid platform game from the looks of it. 2d platformer in a 3d environment, like Pandemonium, or the sidescroller levels in Crash Bandicoot. The catch is that since you are a spider, you can walk up on walls and ceilings, which makes some of the paths very trippy. Also you can get weapons like bombs, boomerangs, guns, poison cannons, which turn you into a half-robotic spider with a cannon arm and such. Your default weapon is just a melee attack, so having ranged attacks will help.


Boxart is actually very accurate in that regard.

>>9603512
I used to read some graphic design textbooks. And I can tell you, a lot of /gd/ fags probably will say these look great.
This is because for years, graphic designers were always taught that "minimalism = good". Blank space? Good and great taste. Minimal typography? Good and great taste. So this was the trend used everywhere in the 70s and 80s. Picrel is an example of it done well. You can see the concept is extremely similar.
The problem is, this just taught a whole profession of faggots who stopped thinking critically, and instead just made blank covers, added typography and a basic image, then gave themselves a pat on the head and jerked to their work with other graphic designers over how "minimalistic" it is. They didn't even think for a second that this is boring and ugly, and hardly makes you excited for a video game.
Hence why everyone hates designers and thinks they are retarded.

Yes he (you) is (are), you fucking autist. Any official definition of "grinding in video games" is going to relate it to RPGs, because there is a fundamental difference between grinding to increase a character's stats so he doesn't get killed in one hit by a boss, and """grinding""" to increase the player's actual real life skill at a game's mechanics.

posts.com: This game was amazing but I had to go back and read about it because it was such a quick cancellation I thought I was just making things up. I never knew less than 100,000 people played, but as an X-files fan it was amazing. If cell phones had higher penetration at the time I think it could have worked, as using the landline at home screwed me on a few phone messages at the time. I've thought about making an app-based version these days, as the tech is finally there, but society is no longer naive enough and people are too jumpy to be faking phone numbers and having randos give breathless clues about people stalking you. From what I remember it was amazing, but it was a moment in time that can never come back. Plus gaslighting is a major industry nowadays, people wouldn't be able to discern the game from the fake reality they already inhabit. Thank you for reading my blog.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596872
>brightness is at about 50% now
That sounds like too much. I have my Trinitron at 3 ticks out of 24 or so, while keeping contrast around the middle of the scale. There is some really slight black crushing, but I get almost true blacks this way.
Remember that "brightness" is the black level setting, and "contrast" is the actual maximum brightness. This has been mislabeled for decades, confusing people to no end. Fortunately some manufacturers have started to change this naming convention to better reflect what those settings do, like LG with their last year OLED models.
Now, to do this adjustment properly you'll need to sit in a dark room and bring out a brightness test pattern of sorts, for example the color bars in the 240p Test Suite. Then you turn down the brightness all the way and make your way up until the bar nearest to black gets barely visible (is a bit brighter than black). Similarly for the contrast, you want to avoid near-white highlights getting blown out, so you should be able to differentiate the value that's nearest to white from pure white. Realistically, you'll probably have to settle on some sort of compromise between true blacks and a bit of black crush as no display is perfect. But hey, that ghosting should be gone at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9604227
240p is strictly speaking an implementation of 480i, with a caveat. 480p is nice at least in principle but it's a pretty narrow subset of displays that can do it and handle 240p input timings properly through the same input (Dreamcast and PS2 are the only consoles with both 240p and 480p games, and not a hell of a lot of the former discounting backwards compatibility, and Dreamcast has issues with games and/or resolution modes outright not supporting certain connectors itself, but still) I don't know a lot about the Dreamcast, but PS2 and Gamecube tend to lower color depth for 480p so it's not an absolute upgrade and probably depends on how your display handles each and your personal preference. On an LCD with bad deinterlacing 480p is going to shit on 480i obviously.

That said, IMO the SNES version of 240p test suite isn't ideal. There's the whole issue with SNES having an internal resolution with a 8:7 aspect ratio that gets stretched to 4:3 with nonsquare pixels. I'm not sure if 240p test suite takes this into account, meaning it's possible if you calibrate geometry using the SNES version it'll be wrong for everything else.

If you have other consoles there are easier ways to use the suite. You can run it off dreamcast since most DCs don't need to be modded to play burned CDs, or run it off a hacked Wii for instance.

>>9616153
Watch a guide to open it up to board level. Then cut small strips of tape to cover the inside edges of the conductive metal pads. This guide is for the switch pro controller, but if you scroll to the end it's the same idea: https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+to+Fix+D-Pad+Sensitivity+on+Switch+Pro+Controller/124493

The only thing is, the amount you cover the pads will affect diagonals sensitivity. So you may need to redo the taping if you do too much or too little.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9616583
Peter Molyneux's last masterpiece before turning into the pathological liar we all know today. It's a weird mixture of management sim, real-time strategy and god game with light rpg elements. The idea is that in a Diablo or a Wizardry or any classic rpg dungeon crawler you play as a hero wandering into a dungeon that's populated with hundreds of different monsters. In Dungeon Keeper you're running the dungeon, building tunnels and different rooms in order to attract more and more vile monsters and then you have to keep them happy, train them up, mine for gold in order to keep them paid and so on. Then occasionally you'll end up tunneling into either another dungeon or you'll be invaded by a group of heroes at which point it becomes something closer to an rts.

Really great and unique. God-tier atmosphere. Good sequel that had a lot of UI and common sense improvements but the atmosphere just wasn't there in the same way. Still an okay follow-up though. In both games the AI's a bit shit but that's forgivable considering it was the late 90s. Only real problem is that there hasn't been a real, true follow-up since DK2. There was a mobile game that was riddled with microtransactions about a decade ago but that's it.

>>9615028
NES
>Batman
>Gremlins 2 : The New Batch
>Vice : Project Doom
>Friday The 13th
>Snake, Rattle & Roll
>Ducktales
>Splatterhouse : Wanpaku Graffiti
>Shadowgate
>Lone Ranger
>S.C.A.T.
The last is a sidescrolling shooter, but it gives you the grace of having a pair of "Options" by default, which you can leave to sweep back and forth to provide an arc of covering fire, or lock in position to help with focusing certain fire.

Game Boy (Color)
>Wario Land (probably one of the best 'Mario' games)
>Wario Land 2
>Pokémon Red/Blue/Yellow
>Pokémon Gold/Silver/Crystal
>The Legend Of Zelda : Link's Awakening
>The Legend Of Zelda : Oracle Of Seasons/Ages (in case you missed these)
>Metroid II : The Return Of Samus (ditto)
>Tetris
>Kirby's Pinball Land
>Duke Nukem
Duke Nukem is a re-imagining of Duke Nukem 2, in a rather cartoony style. A lot better than you'd expect from seeing the Duke Nukem 3D artwork slapped onto a Game Boy Color cartridge.

SNES
>Super Metroid
>True Lies (was also on Genesis in virtually identical guise)
>Arkanoid II : Doh It Again
>Wild Guns
>Harvest Moon
>Clock Tower
>Actraiser
>Final Fight 3
>Kirby's Avalanche
>Earthbound
Earthbound has an overblown reputation (yet also an exaggerated hatedom), and can be slightly rough to get into, but it has a lot of charm, and is worth taking a look at if you like JRPGs. There was nothing else like it back then, and later imitators don't compare.

Genesis
>Puyo Puyo
>Splatterhouse 2 (the first one was only in arcades and on TurboGfx16 in the west)
>Splatterhouse 3 (consider the Japanese ROM for a far less sadistic time limit)
>Shining Force
>Quack Shot : Starring Donald Duck
>Ghostbusters
>Columns
>Devilish
>The Ooze
>Zero Tolerance
There's also Michael Jackson's Moonwalker, which maybe isn't all that great of a game, but it's interesting for its novelty, and for hearing some sweet tunes transcribed to YM2612.

I'd have thrown in GBA as well for a full 50, but maybe later.

These days it remains a version of pre-OB HL2 which the PC can't easily provide, even cracked copies are a little annoying to fuck with today making the Xbox version a stable solution to those curious.

Odd to throw a critique of obsolescence in order to dismiss an old game on a retro games board. I think if you have a genuine interest in source games, old versions especially- HL2 Xbox provides a lot to enjoy. It doesn't work like normal HL2 does anymore.

>Half-Life really wasn't much of a property on consoles.

The Dreamcast port was the most anticipated game on the console, people were literally talking about how it was going to "save the Dreamcast". Blue Shift was originally intended to be a DC exclusive. The PS2 port was the definitive version for a long time thanks to the ultradetailed models.

It wasn't Halo by any means, and the HL2 port was more of an afterthought than a system seller, but the franchise still had a presence on consoles. Hell, the original Xbox even had a pretty solid port of Counter Strike that was one of the highest ranked games on Xbox Live in terms of player count.

>>9620493
The game won't output 480p unless you specifically tell it to (whether through a button input or a menu option).

There were 480i CRTs that featured component input back in the day, which meant the PS2 couldn't get away with doing something dumb like auto booting to 480p just because the console output was set to YCbCr. That being said I would look for a scaling device that does support 480p since progressive scan is very nice when a game supports it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I can't believe this board has become so useless. Nobody came even close to answering OPs actual question.

First of all, as far as I know, 480p is never enabled by default in any game on the PS2. Including the DVD menu, for what it's worth.

But to make it even simpler, you really have two options if you want to use your PS2 on a modern flatscreen.
1. Just use composite cables running into the RetroTink 2X Pro. Composite cables on the PS2 do not support progressive scan, so the system will always output 480i. Every PS2 game supports 480i, and the 2x Pro will de-interlace this (essentially removing the bottom field, then doubling the top field I guess) to make it 480p for your modern television. Easy peasy.
2. Pony up for a 5x Pro, which is probably way more than you want to spend, but DOES support 480p pass through, as well as can handle 1080i inputs, which some PS2 games do support (though most people say these settings unilaterally look like shit, I've never seen it myself since I use a CRT). Either way using a 5x-Pro your childhood favorite ATV Offroad Fury 2 will look as good as it possibly can running out of original hardware onto a modern TV.

This is a significantly more complicated process, but
3. Softmod your PS2 (basically, buy a Free McBoot memory card on ebay, google it) and get GSM running, which is a piece of homebrew software will allow you to force your PS2 into whatever settings you prefer. I don't think it really makes sense for you to do, but it can force 480i games into 480p so you could run it into a much less expensive digitizer than the 2X Pro. You'd still need a way to get it going though, so probably pointless...

Either way, hope that helps.

posts.com: I think UG1-THAW had a constant progression of polish. UG1 opened up the game from the classic arcade play, but I think they didn't get a clear sense of direction until UG2. American Wasteland perfected not only the skating, but also made the off board movement as bearable as it could possibly get. The themes of American Wasteland were cringe in retrospect (but it came out during peak 2000s MTV edge so it didn't feel that way on release if you were younger.) Saturn wasn't underpowered so much as just really difficult to program for. The best games on the system could match or exceed the PlayStation, but it was rare to see it. Most ports to Saturn from PlayStation look worse because A) it was harder to program for and B) publishers probably didn't care because Saturn was significantly less popular.
Check out stuff like Powerslave, Duke 3D, Quake, Sonic Jam (Sonic World), Sonic R and Virtua Fighter 2 to see what it was capable of.

>>9583547
NTA, but.
Point-and-click game with copious CGI, impressive production values, batshit insane plot, full voice acting, and it impressed Nintendo so much they hired a lot of the staff for their EAD team. It's Japan-only, for the moment being. Only times it got talked about before was when collector hoarders accidentally leaked a private mega folder with tons of games including this previously lost game.
Company did 3 games like these and folded shortly after. Supposedly uses a Macromedia type thing.

Some copyright troll trademarked a bunch of stuff including the logo for the game and took down most of the media about it online, and it looks more like erasing the game from existence than a prospective new release. Nearly nothing is left online.

The game is about a 5 year old American girl identifying as a bear (and portrayed as such) going to dangerous locations after hearing voices in her head. The game opens with her being refused a bus ride, that bus is bombed by terrorists and everyone is dead, the terrorists are gunned by an airplane and everyone is dead, and the girl inspects the bus and goes "It can't be helped". Then she has to avoid dying by starvation, getting hugged to death by a pedophile cop, getting killed in the crossfire of other terrorists in a public park where a schizophrenic woman thinks the heroine is daughter, and then an alien locale that defies description. I'm saddened the walkthrough was taken offline. I really want to see how this goes now that I learned more Japanese. The backstory intro roll itself (which is in English) alone is a riot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9596951
>>9596953
Anon who posted that. It's still the original files, but they are preinstalled on an emulated Windows 98 Machine so the game is easy to play

The ISO file is in a folder titled 'Files' along with the Windows 98 drive, and is mounted to the machine so the game can run, but is also there to make it easier to use and explore compared to the format of the original files

To run the machine, run "Launch.bat" in the folder

>qemu-system-i386 -nodefaults -rtc base=localtime -display sdl -L pc-bios -m 256 -machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off -device VGA -device lsi -device sb16 -drive file=Files/w98.qcw -cdrom Files/CB1_DISC.iso -boot c

Its just a one line command that launches the machine with the correct settings, but I obviously get not wanting to run some random batch script and exe, so you can also move the files to your own qemu install and it'll work fine

>>9600572
Not much, but there are two things you can try that may help.

First is to change '256' to '512' to increase the amount of memory the machine has, though I don't know if this will really help.

The other, if you are on Windows and have the Windows Hypervisor Platform enabled, is to change this
>-machine pc,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off
to this
>-machine pc,accel=whpx,hpet=off,usb=off,kernel-irqchip=off
which will improve the general performance through virtualization

This can cause some issues related to shutting down the emulated machine though, but its nothing major

I'd like to report that it runs on Wine 7.0.1 pretty much out of the box.

You actually can run Wine on Windows by using WSL2. That way you're still using a VM, but it'll be a sensibly fast one (modern Windows hosting a modern Linux guest) rather than a bug-ridden one (modern Windows trying to run a Win 98 guest).
Just download the "Ubuntu" app from your Windows Store and then `sudo apt install wine` and hey presto you've got Wine.

For anons who are suffering from bad sound running the Windows 98 QEMU VM, it's probably due to QEMU's poorly emulated SoundBlaster sound card.
In comparison the AC97 codec is much more open and accurately emulated.
To try that, change "-device sb16" to "-device ac97".
Then you'll need to install the driver. One possibility to to search for the "SigmaTel C-Major Audio AC97 WDM driver".

>>9604896
Good or not depends on if you like point-and-clicks. As for interesting, yes. It's a pretty high level of Japanese weirdness with pretty good (for 1999 PC games) production values.

It's about a 5 year old girl from New Jersey named Cookie Blair who sees herself as a teddy bear, the intro gives the backstory that a century ago aliens arrived on an island in the South Pacific and made an agreement with the island's president where they could own a part of the land if they shared their technology with him. They eventually started an annual Olympics-like sports contest, which Cookie wants to enter.

The very first thing that happens in the game is Cookie loses her bus pass, the bus driver kicks her off the bus, and then as the bus drives away some people drive up in a jeep with a rocket launcher and blow up said bus... which causes a helicopter to arrive and blast away said people and then fly away. There is apparently an alternate version of that scene where the rocket people and helicopter blow each other up.

It's also possible to die in the crossfire of two gangs in the middle of the park, pick up a spirit radio that lets you hear (ghost?) sex, die from smoking, find Laura Croft's corpse in a tomb, win a dance-off, and break out of jail. I am sure there are dozens of other weird scenarios I haven't encountered.

It's pretty wacky.

Of course I mean inside qemu (more accurately inside Windows 98). WDM is the Windows 9x driver type, not NT (i.e. Win 10).

>>9606821
If you mean the audio cutting during cutscenes, I don't how to resolve that.

But if you mean the audio being distorted and stuttery, that can be fixed by disabling hardware acceleration on the sound output inside of Windows 98.

You can do this by going to the Control Panel, then 'Multimedia', and then selecting 'Advanced Properties' on the playback device. Then select 'Performance' at the top and use the slider to disable hardware acceleration.

This is caused using the ac97 instead of the sb16

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Repost from >>>/v/625694309

How you can help with a translation

Yes, we need someone fluent in Japanese, with the same skillset needed for translating audio dramas or anime (less than 40 minutes of audio).
The audio is extracted as individual files with filenames out of their context.
That translator would need to transcribe all of them to Japanese (to make later revisions easier) first.
Then give his/her own interpretation of the text in English second.

Audio files are already extracted, but not organized in a very friendly way.

>https://mega.nz/folder/IGcQ3CJa#P6VUlCjXAJxdoiZHgqBLMQ
Get this file
>Asset rips/Audio Dump WAV.zip
It has all ingame sfx, bgm and voice acting, except for the movies.
They're all short wav files named like this
>dirOpened output of nms-1683.wav

From what I noticed, they seem to be following this trend:
>nms
general voice acting (1683 files)
>sky, swm
minigame voice acting / sfx (43 files)
>cly, ffh, hdl
more minigame voice acting / sfx (74 files)
>acs
mostly sound effects and grunts and background music, but some are voice acting like acs-196 to acs-206 which cover saving/loading the game. better saved for last (216 files)

Same mega.nz folder has another file for the movies.
>Asset rips/Movies.zip
Only a handful have voice acting.
They can be hard subbed probably, but a transcription would be better even for stuff that's in voiced/written in Engrish because the audio quality is generally poor.

For the transcript to be useful it could be formatted this way:

>acs-200
>オープニングムービーを見る?
>Watch the opening movie?

as a text file, covering all of the game files.
If you don't want to type acs/nms every time you can just type the number and just clarify which section it is in the beginning of the file.

>acs-196 to acs-206
Those audio strings already have matching visual text in English even in the Japanese version.
So the acs files are low priority, but should be checked just in case.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9609140
>Dumping (and maybe recompiling) the game's scripting seems possible, but I'm not even sure if Director supports any kind of subtitles. Have to go dig through the old documentation.

>What we have now
All of the audio extracted from the cxt/cst files: Can be transcribed and given a text translation
All of the movies are in an easily editable format that can be hard subbed
All visual elements are already in English: Don't need a translation
Sprites and all of their individual animation frames are easily extracted in Macromedia editor from cxt/cst files

>How the project can move forward

>Dub route - easiest, but worst
The extracted audio can be replaced with English equivalents. Not that many voice actors. However, it would lose SOUL.
The videos can be redubbed or subtitled fairly easily like old documentary shows

>In-Engine Sub route - keeps compatibility with W95, but might be glitchy/not possible
New images are added through Macromedia editor for all possible voiced lines. English text on a transparent background.
The game logic in Macromedia Director needs to be deobfuscated (still not done yet), every single audio call will be changed to call those new textures, they'd appear for a fixed duration of time (length of the voiced line) and then disappear
Might be done via cxt/cst modding but unsure.

>Modern Enhancement Sub route - ideal, but hardest
The executable, a glorified Macromedia Director projector, is modded in IDA Pro to intercept any calls for audio playback and displays proper soft subtitles overlaid on top of the screen from an external srt file with proper timing data (might help with multi-line subtitles, and more importantly the subs are no longer held back by the engine limitations + multi language translations are possible) - of course an external text renderer might need to be coded but that's really easy
While you're at it, it could intercept mov playback and override them with AI upscaled versions of the movies

This impersonator is committing tortious interference against the original developers, and is the one who actually needs to be sued for damages.

>>9618752
this thread concerned a guy who said his 2600 glitched when running a Harmony cart but it was fine with normal carts. if i had to guess it's that the Harmony induced voltage sag that caused the CPU to become unstable (as it draws more power than a normal cart). spraying it with compressed air temporarily fixed the problem. he swapped the CPU with a different one and it cleared up the issue. it may be that the original 6507 was a bit twitchier about its voltage level. back in the Atari times IC manufacturing wasn't as consistent as it is today and components could have more variance in their operating characteristics.

essentially as the CPU warm ups, its power use increases and the extra power draw from the Harmony overdid it and caused it to glitch from insufficient voltage. that's just my pet theory.

posts.com: My quest to play as many Famicom RPGs as I can continues

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Just Breed
Tactical RPG which unlike Fire Emblem leans more towards the RPG elements. You can explore towns, talk to people, shop, etc However the combat is tactical grid based. Unlike in FE or Famicom Wars, an attacked unit will not retaliate on the turn it is attacked. Gameplay is based around generals, the player has up to 4 teams each with 1 general and 5 units composed of fighters, archers, and mages (offensive or defensive). Units belonging to a general can not leave the current screen the general is on, so it is him that gives the overall movement of the team.
Nice graphics and musics. Difficulty a bit on the easy side. You can replay battles to grind for exp/gold and the game seems to expect you to do that at least if you want to buy an acceptable amount of gear in shops.
What's impressive about it is the amount of characters the game can have on the screen at once. The game uses background graphics for the characters, unless it is currently the unit in play in which case it will turn into sprites for the time being. Smart.
On the bad side, the game rarely goes beyond the battle->town->repeat routine. Most of the game has the same two musics on loop (battle and town), despite the musics being of quality. A waste on that side as well as with graphics, a mangaka was hired for monster designs but you only see enemy designs in small windows when you select them (there are no battle anims).
Also, the game insists on using the same few palettes for the majority of towns, even when it really doesn't fit. All of this makes the game very monotonous.

All in all the game feels like a wasted opportunity: published by Enix, allegedly took 3 years to dev and hired famous mangaka and composer, and all that for what? A tired town->battle routine, "tactical" gameplay that can easily boil down to "just grind lol", enemy design in small windows that you don't get to see, and the same two musics looping for most of the game.
It IS a good game, but it should have been more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Moryo Senki Madara

By Konami, based on a Manga license unknown to me, but the double page ad for this game was all over Japanese magasines at the time of release. The story failed to catch my interest and felt like you had to know the original work to fully enjoy it.
Great soundtrack using the same soundchip as Castlevania 3, there are even several world map themes.
Good graphics with Konami's trademark huge characters, lot's of great looking graphical cutscenes.
Combat is turned based, but top down and semi automatic: you can pause the action at any time to input commands for the next turn(s). Characters/enemies move around the screen to attack. For a semi-automatic system, there is a surprising amount of tactic involved and battles often get exciting.
Sprites are small during combat, but you get a graphical view of the enemies Dragon Quest style before battles which I appreciated a lot (they knew the impact of such graphics on the player, vs their small sprites during combat which rarely looked menacing)
Until the late game and revive item/spell, you do NOT want any character to die. You have to go through hell to get them back AND they will lose all their gear and items.
The game can get really brutal in difficulty, at least until you figure out a couple of tricks (one involves grinding the physical and magical attack power stats easily and quickly, the other involves protective spells).
Seasons change with time on the overworld map, a couple of events are tied to it.
The game is fairly long too. Exploration and dungeons get more complicated and interesting as the game goes on, perhaps a bit too many floor pits and teleporters in the late game dungeons.
In some ways, it felt like this game paved the way for Lagrange Point.
[cont]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9619425
[cont]


On the down side:
-Took a bit too long to be able to use spells conveniently, at first they're rare and expensive to use.
-The game LOVES to take away your characters for story reasons, and with them their gear and items which you do not get back even when the character is back.
-Too much barren land on the overworld map
-You have 2 protagonists plus 2 allies whom you can change, however it took too long to have a real choice of allies, by that point it was a downgrade to change. I only changed once despite the great amount of characters to choose from.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Kaijuu Monogatari (Shell Monsters Story)

Surprisingly good DQ(2) clone from 88.
The game shines with its exploration and its characters system. There are 4 characters, each starts the game on a different side of the world map. You can start with anyone, switch to any character at any point.
The world is your playground with a LOT of unlinearility and exploration. You could probably replay the game 5 times and do things in a different order, or differently, every time.
The priority at first is to gather the 4 characters together, but once that's done you're free to split the team any way you like any time. This also becomes mandatory after a while due to treasure hunting at sea as the boat only carries two people.
The battle system is DQ2-like, but looks very dynamic: you can see your characters on the screen, and each enemy changes to a "wounded" variant when about to die.

While that unlinearility is the game's strength, it is also its weakness: it is hard to balance a game in which the player is allowed to go to many places in any order. At the very beginning difficulty is brutal, but after a while you're guaranteed to play 1 or 2 areas in which enemies won't be able to make a scratch anymore, although it is still possible to walk into a later area by chance and suddenly stumble on much stronger enemies (like in Final Fantasy 2), although area limitations are clearly marked for the most part. Also the entire late-end game spices thing up properly.

Overworld/town/dungeon graphics are okay, but characters and enemies graphics in battle have a lot of charm.

Musics are hit&miss, some good tracks, some not so good, sadly the two songs you'll be hearing the most belong in the not-so-good department.

[cont]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9619435
[cont]

Not much going on in the story department.
On the bad side, I found that offensive spells were barely if ever worth using. Also, middle to high grade gear is scattered all around the world so at some point once the team is gathered, some backtracking is required just for that. Also, the interface and text is a bit slow. Finally, the translation available had some graphical glitches and a couple of misses.

Tip: use the world map provided with the manual, write down the name of the towns on it; and write down every clue NPCs give you. Doing that emphasizes the sense of adventure, I only needed a guide for one nasty non-hinted key item at the very end of the game.
Same dev/publisher later on made Jubei Quest, re-using a lot of mechanics and ideas from this game, albeit with more linearility. While Shell Monsters Story is a DQ2 clone and emphasized the adventure-exploration elements, Jubei Quest is more of a DQ3 clone: more linear, but bigger, with more varied environments and more focus on story.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Digital Devil Story - Megami Tensei

The first in a long series for Atlus (the sequel easily being one of the best RPGs on Famicom), this first person dungeon crawler has quite a reputation for being very hard. I didn't think it was that hard, and grinding goes a long way (you will need to, to some extent, at the very least before entering the 2nd and 3rd areas) but it can definitely be tedious.
There are two party members, and then you get to recruit demons for an extra 3 party members. You can then fuse demons together to end up with more powerful demons.
The game gets easier once you get the spell that allows you to return to town, and also if you manage to recruit that optional demon which gives you a revive spell early on, but you may still occasionally get fucked by traps or a horde of demons ambushing you.
For 1987, the game is MASSIVE, it takes probably a good 60-70 hours to beat especially if you make your own maps (looking them up wouldn't be the same). Combats can really drag on too. There is quite a bit of unlinearility.
The game looks pretty good, especially for '87, and especially the monster design.

I have to warn that one should play via emulation and set the emulator savestate auto-save function to every 5 mins or so. From the mid point onward, I got a LOT of crashes, some recurrent ones too related to certain enemy types which I then usually ran from to avoid the crashes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Dragon Warrior 4 is still the best

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Momotarou Densetsu (The Legend of the Peach Boy)

Late '87 DQ1 clone by Hudson based on popular Japanese story. 1 on 1 battles with occasional help from AI partner in battle. Very grindy even by Famicom RPG standard, almost DQ1-tier. For 87' the game sounds and looks great, and battles, menus, text are all very fast and smooth. Lot's of humour and some charm.
However, the game drops the cake pretty hard starting from the mid point of the game. Suddenly, the item puzzles for progression are cryptic (even with the in game clues included) and the game does everything in its power to be as obnoxious and annoying as possible: NPCs that warp you to another point of the world map (several times), enemies that can steal all your money and items and flee from battle with it, tons of enemies which can heal themselves to full HP making fights last forever, enemies ambushing you and getting to hit you 3 times in 1 turn or freezing you, etc etc the game just won't stop trolling.
This, on top of the grind and the fact that useful late game healing items can only be acquired through a luck based mini game, makes the experience very painful and I can't recommend the game before of that.

Somehow this game spawned an entire series, including an untranslated Famicom sequel. Also, it feels like it was influencial to the genre, as many small things this game did would find their way to other (better) RPGs: the AI partners can be found in Musashi no Bouken and SD Keiji - Blader, the humour (including a 4th wall breaking joke mentionning the console itself) in Ninjara Hoi!, the way the teleport spells involves an animation showing the character go around the world map physicall in Jubei Quest (and Ninjara Hoi! too iirc), and there is also progression being alted by a fat sleeping monster blocking the road, that you have to find a way to wake up (Pokémon).
posts.filename: Momotaru Densetsu (The Legend of Peach Boy)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>SD Gundam Story Knight Gundam Legend

Very obvious DQ clone, everything in the system and menus is identical to DQ2/3. Even the character are, at first, reminiscent of classes found in DQ3, until they start to shine on their own.
However the game is surprisingly very good, the graphics and musics are great and there is a lot of charm to the world. Balancing isn't too bad overall (there are issues, like your characters having Def so high they are dealt 1 dmg from physical attacks, but can easily get OHKO'd or close by spells).
You play as a hero + 3 other party members chosen from 6 allies total.
The game also has tons of good and interesting ideas, for instance in battle you have an option to go behind enemies, there is an item which on the world map lets you see ahead of you, you can mark spots in dungeons to help get your bearings, a party member left at the base may occasionally join a battle as a 5th AI controlled partner and gain exp from the battle, etc etc.
There is also a card mini game based on an IRL card game (the price of a card is even the same!). However, there isn't much to the card battles themselves as they're just AI controlled 1on1 RPG battles, but they can be used to gain exp and gold.
On the bad side: dungeons are very drab and samey. I felt there are a bit too many towns too, or rather the size of the world doesn't warrant that many so close to each others.
The end game and ending are VERY disappointing and left a very sour taste. You go through a cave that leads to the end castle. Neither the cave nor the castle have random encounters. Then, the game taunts you with a boss rush that doesn't happen, followed by a final boss which is just a buffed up version of a boss already fought earlier in the game (while the hero has been buffed up insanely), while the real villain just leaves and the game hints at playing the sequel.
What a terrible end game! There are two sequels on Famicoms but neither have been translated so far.
posts.filename: SD Gundam Story - Knight Gundam Legend

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Niji no Silkroad (Rainbow Silkroad)

A somewhat different concept in this RPG with no experience points and very few visible stats.
You must go along the silkroad and trade goods in order to raise money, which you will use to buy equipment that raise your HP and attack and even eventually hire party members, in order to solve quests and go through dungeons within a kingdom before moving on to the next kingdom.
The game is very one dimensional, grindy, and frankly quite a bore because of it. Combats are all about the attack button, your only other option being a couple of items which would NEVER work when I attempted to use them, dungeons all look the same throughout the entire game (same tiles, same palette) so there is very little to keep the player entertained.
Graphics and music are okay, and the historical tidbits are fun, but other than that the idea behind the game was more fun than the game itself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>The Magic Candle

A DQ1 clone from 1992 which for the time looks outdated: there is no scrolling, the FOV is half the screen, and the mechanics are very simple. I thought it was a port of a 1989 computer game of the same name, but they have nothing to do with each others.
However I found the game to have a lot of charm. The musics and art style have a lot of charm, especially the enemies graphics which are some of the best looking I've seen on the system and are very big.
Story is simple DQ1 style as well but with a bit more dialogue, and there is charm to be found in that if it's your sort of things. The game is seperated in chapters, with a couple of plotwists along the way, and you can't backtrack to areas pertaining to previous chapters.
Combat is 1vs1 but, as per tradition with DQ1 clones, along the way you get an AI partner that occasionally attack or use spells in combat, but unlike in SD Keiji - Blader, Musashi no Bouken and Momotaru Densetsu, the AI partern is actually very useful. You get just about as many spells as in DQ1, with similar functions.
Difficulty seems spot on at first, with a little bit of grind required, but around the mid point the game becomes a breeze you can just waltz through with no worry. Shame! It would have gained in being a little bit harder. As a result the game feels pretty short.
There is a day/night cycle but it doesn't seem to make much difference, though you do get a count of how many days it took you to beat the game at the end.
It is worth noting that spells seemed to power up as the hero did, but with an added downside of consuming more MP (so I often didn't know how much MP a spell would cost)
If DQ1 is your thing, you should try this game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Shinsenden - The Legend of Immortals

1989 game by Tamtext and Irem (I keep saying every publisher on Famicom released at least one RPG)
Good graphics (there is shading in towns/dungeons), good music. The story is a bit more than your usual "kill evil overworld" but the dialogues and cutscenes go way too fast to truly appreciate it, although the many references to ancient cultures help make it seem more mature.
You can run in towns, you can carry up to 16 items per character (versus the traditional 8, and you're gonna need them!), battle speed can be set to "so fast you barely have time to realize wtf is going on" plus you can make the loading of fights faster by holding a button. Message speed is pretty fast too, I never once felt like hitting the fast forward key. When you target a dead enemy, you will automatically attack the next enemy (though only within the same group). All of this makes grinding really fast, and are the kind of QOL the vast majority of Famicom RPGs (and even beyond) lack.
Tons of interesting mechanics: you have spells and skills, each with their own MP pools. Starting from chapter 2 onward you can also absorb most enemies and then summon them for use in battle, each absorbed enemy can be used once but they have infinite MP. They have to be used intelligently for healing/fighting/tanking and it's an essential mechanic in some parts of the game. Also, blocking actually matters a lot, and when you are low on health, enemies deal less damage and you are more likely to dodge attacks. So the game is challenging but forgiving at the same time (I once managed to make it back to town with 1hp left, that included surviving a fight with that 1 HP).

[cont]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9619475
[cont]


But yes the game is very challenging (did I mention that running away from battles never work? At least until you get a spell for it). You will need to grind a bit in each chapter, then each move matters, each item slot too, each spell/skill use etc On top of this, if the hero dies, it's game over, and it's back to the previous save file (no respawning with half your money like in most DQ clones). You only get a revive spell at the very end and I believe it can only be used to revive the 3rd party member. That on top of all the interesting mechanics gives this game a tactical edge over many other RPGs of the kind.

On the downside there isn't much in the way of exploration, especially in the overworld. The game is divided in a chapter format and each chapter takes place in its small island with 1-2 towns and dungeons each. Also the game likes to take characters away from your party abruptly.

Overall one of the most underrated Famicom RPGs (neither a mobygames nor a wikipedia page?) which shines manly thanks to its neat QOL and mechanics, the challenge it provides, and the story that's a bit more than the usual. It is challenging and a bit grindy however, but the grind goes fast, and the game is definitely too short (about 16-18 hours long)!

it's much cheaper to get funtastic or solid black plastic like that molded through china than it is to get a more authentic solid white/beige plastic. going translucent also means that the hobbyists designing these don't have to worry about the actual texture on the surface plastic and thus use even cheaper finishes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9620571
Mods, or .wads, since that's the file format used ever since December 10, 1993, even if more advanced GzDoom mods tend to use .pk3 formats these days. Anyway, the author of Ashes made a version which uses the stock Doom 2 enemies, weapons and items, so that you could either play it that way, or play it with all kinds of different gameplay mods.

Anyway, if you enjoy the original Doom and Doom 2, then you're in luck because for close to 30 years now, people have been making cool shit for it, Ashes being one of many, and there's just these vast treasure hoards of stuff for the game.
Most of the content is level sets of all kinds, but there's a LOT of gameplay mods, and a number of Partial Conversions and Total Conversions. If you're interested in more TCs, there's Action Doom 2, Rekkr, and Total Chaos, to name some.
You also have Partial Conversions such as Pirate Doom, which is to a large part Doom 2 gameplay still, but the pirate theme is committed to very lovingly, and it's incredibly charming.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ashes is one of my favorite games of all time. I find the 1st one flows better, but the 2nd has much higher quality overall. I do think the 2nd one lacks heavily in some areas, which feel very desolate. He went for more of an open world approach, which feels unnecessary once you progress through an area nothing respawns so it just lends to a lot of backtracking, and potentially getting lost looking for where to go next.

Overall, I give the franchise 9/10, and its easily in my top 10 of all time.

Forced meme by underage pseuds, who have been fed third-hand accounts originating from 40+ year old grognards who are upset that first person shooters weren't all Quake and Unreal Tournament until the end of time.

>>9618714
See? You're anencephalic, Half-Life's level design is fairly linear, but it's also full of intersections, optional areas, and exploration, various hubs can be done in no particular order, etc. If you had said Half-Life 2, I would at least have gotten it, because it's a good bit more linear than the first one, but you haven't actually played either game. The kinds of straight line designs consisting mostly of increasingly scripted setpieces is something which Call Of Duty would pioneer, and that series didn't even get into that formula for real until the mid/late 2000s. The first Half-Life's level design is closer to Duke Nukem 3D than it is, say, Call Of Duty: Black Ops.

Some blame is put on Halo for popularizing regenerating health as a crutch for weak level design, but it was the sequels which really got that going. In the first Halo you had regenerating SHIELDS, on top of a limited healthpool which would not refill itself for you, if you took damage beyond your shields, you would have to go and find some health to get it back, or you would just have to hope that you wouldn't take too much damage later.
It's not a mechanic which appeals to me, because it's kind of just a boring way to make the game easier, but it's a lot better than later shooters, where as long as you got away and went to hide, no injury would ever have any kind of consequences, Master Chef at least had to manage his health as a resource in some capacity.

They have been mentioned already, but it's basically:
>Arcade games being developed as pocket drainers with unreal difficulty spikes so people used more and more coins.
>Memory capacity didn't allow for long games so there was some padding achieved with the difficulty, with RPGs coming to mind with the jump into home consoles.
>A community built around solving puzzles and riddles, constantly having a back and forth with the developers for clues or ideas. The Wizardry games in the west and other PC ones, for example.
>Third party groups (translators, coders to move games across platforms, etc.) being massives dicks for no reason. Suffice to say, the retards at Working Designs have a place reserved in hell for this.
>Games were mostly designed as being a challenge, and not a time sinker to wind down. You had adventure games and sims and that, but the business model was different from the current one that favors a casual approach.

posts.sub: FPS weapon keybindings. What do you use?
posts.com:
For some games it makes more sense to use default numbers but I started to remap if possible using:
1) Assault Rifle
2) Pistol/SMG/Secondary Weapons/Required Weapon/Rocket?
3) Shotgun/Flamethrower/Close combat weapon/Rocket?
4) Sniper Rifle/Bow/Rocket?
5,6) Other weapons

Using keys up to 5 is very easy 6 is also quite usable. From that point on you have remap them to make use them quickly. In the past for UT2004 I was using Q, E, R, F, V, Z, X, C and so on. This depends on the game because for some games you have other actions for those buttons. At that point I tried using F1-F4 but not sure whether that's a good idea.
I also started to remap grenade to middle mouse and melee V or F button. Despite older FPSes treating them as a different weapons instead of actions this still feels better.
HUD in games like Half-Life doesn't work as intended like this but it's fine.

If you can't carry more than 4 weapons and have to use something like Rocket for a section I generally change 2's weapon given that does have an alternative with 1. Although this depends on which weapons you want to carry. I generally go for the first options of my list.

>>9616460
Many 70s/early 80s arcade games used discrete analog audio circuits to generate sound effects. They are pretty complex to rebuild in emulation (MAME used prerecorded .wav files with Donkey Kong for ages instead of emulating the circuits). FPGA doesn't offer any advantages with their recreation either.

>>9614920
There's really no need to fix the combat.

You see; Morrowind makes you specialize. The way old table top games do like DnD.

If you didn't choose magic options in your character creation? GUESS WHAT? You're gonna dice roll on spells for a LONG time until you level it up or spend the gold for training which you CAN do. Can go total blade sword or something easily.

But if you pick agility as a main attribute and (Insert weapon skill) as one of your primaries from the get go. Then GUESS WHAT; You'll HIT WITH YOUR WEAPON A LOT MORE OFTEN! Could argue it even adds some realism to the game like imagine a kid trying to use a sword for the first time... he'd SUCK AT IT>

It's that simple. Morrowind doesn't hold your hand but there are a gazillion guides out there that can help you achieve whatever desired effect/character you want. Hell if playing on PC or xbox there are even some glitches or console commands you can use to make damn sure you never miss again. It's a little cheaty but if missing swings filters you so hard well there's always oblivion and skyrim... The watered down versions of elder scrolls that came later. Oblivion had some potential in areas but idk maybe it was rushed in development or something. The vanilla game is so fucking boring. The DLC is... not bad.

I didn't hate Skyrim; I just wasn't over satisfied with it. I play through it sometimes but if I had to choose one of them to be stuck with; it's morrowind every time.
It's got insane depth to it, a bad ass main story line. Excellent DLC. And the most memorable moments and characters/missions.

>>9618447
The game was designed to be playable using 33.6k models that shipped with European consoles. You'll be fine over dialup.

I think PSO is a lot of fun in solo mode, although it'll obviously be more difficult and you'll be missing out on the fun of co-op. It can feel very zen by yourself though, and it's definitely a game I enjoy replaying.

I'm a Dreamcastfag but honestly at this point if you're interested in playing PSO it will be better to check out one of the versions that has the Episode 2 content. The base game (Episode 1) has four zones. Each zone has two levels, plus a boss area at the end of the second level. Episode 2 adds like six or seven new zones, so it's a shitload more content. The Dreamcast version (both the original, and ver2) are both just Episode 1. The X-Box, Gamecube, and PC versions all have Episodes 1 and 2.

Also, don't forget to feed your mag.

posts.com:
just tried it myself starting last week, playing on my gdemu Dreamcast. I was of the right age to have played it in its time but just never got a Dreamcast.

it's a bit of a repetitive snooze, but I'm ambivalent about it rather than negative. the combat feels more immediate than most MMOs because continuing a combo is timing-based. death results in penalties per the trends of its time, you lose all your carried money and as far as I can tell a random selection of your carried items--if you drop your weapon, especially at the beginning, this is a big fuck in your ass. environments are tunnels and spreads, reminding me a lot of pre-World monster hunter, except less visually distinctive so you're absolutely gonna get your ass lost.

despite that visually it's joyful like every Sega game that generation, very comfy. the music is also very nice, so atmospherically altogether it's a great time. maybe it's just my race/class combo but the PC walk cycles look a bit retarded, and I wish there was a faster way to get around in the maps than their doofy leisurely jog.

this is a summation based on a blind about 4 hours of single-player so take it with the grain of salt that suggests. it's been fun to muck around in so far but I don't feel a great compulsion to keep playing it. coming into the dragon fight completely underprepared but somehow coming out successful was hype though, I admit.

The real problem was the downfall of BASIC, which used to be a nearly universal lingua franca for every computer out there and as long as you relegated yourself to using the more or less universally implemented subset of functions you could be a full bore user developer and write software that would run on most any computer in existence, from University time-sharing systems to personal computers. Sure the OS makers and professional software writers would use a different language most of the time but countless small software businesses flourished and hobbyists themselves produced a shitload of software too.

Once BASIC went away and the industry started moving toward expensive proprietary toolkits with ever-shifting OS and dev stacks it was all over for the hobbyist industry because programming became much more complicated.

posts.name: Anonymous
