>>9614528
It's a complicated matter, but from what I understand, the British industry had been declining since the late 60s or the early 70s. As the result of nationalist and supply and demand economic policies, there was little incentive to invest on manufacturing tools and improving labour skills. Manufacturing cost was expensive compared to their competitors, so most of the British wealthy chose to invest in the service sector. Politicians like Callaghan tried to push back against this shift and make British manufacturing competitive again by taxing the service sector, limiting pay raises and such, but it was met with heavy pushback which led to what was known as "Winter of Discontent". Thus, Thatcher was elected, and she deregulated the market while pursuing a monetarist policy that hurt British exports. Trade unions were seen to be a scary and powerful that threatened the crumbling British industry back then, but Thatcher's policy to remove their bargaining power altogether was proved even more detrimental to the industry

TL;DR manufacturing lost, finance won. They couldn't keep up with the rapid pace of the Japanese and German industry, and those who tried to save it did a few blunders that caused a pushback. Ultimately, most of the western world was flirting with neoliberal policies that reduced the power of their industrial sector as manufacturing jobs and tools were sent over to the eastern world for maximum profits, but Britain certainly doubled down on it.

Soviet and Eastern Bloc kids were obtaining surplus computer chips, usually clones of the Z80, and making their own home computers from junk parts they scrounged up because it was the only way to get a home computer unless your parents worked for the Politburo or something like that. But all the smarter kids were channeled into computer education classes too, there. Schools frequently had computer labs starting in the 1980s, it was seen as necessary to compete with the west. It's one of the reason there's so many good Russian and Eastern European hackers and computer programmers.

Today the Russians still make Speccy clones, often massively enhanced with multiple megabytes of memory, better sound and video capabilities, hard drive support, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9599906
70s-80s chips were often NMOS logic. This is when all the transistors in the chip are n-doped. It has the disadvantage of using a lot of power and getting hot as it forces every transistor in the chip to draw current even when idling, and it also produces a lot of signal line noise and can have glitchy behavior due to how the logic works.

All modern chips (anything designed in the last 30+ years) are CMOS logic, which is a mix of p and n-doped transistors. It is much more efficient and cooler running as idling transistors do not use any power and it's free of signal line noise and glitches. However it was not widely used for years as it was more complex to manufacture and early CMOS chips were very slow (solved when they found they could just thin the metallization layer). CMOS chips are less forgiving of sloppy system design as they can be damaged by a bus conflict as that will drive the signal lines on the chip high, while NMOS signal lines would go low.

Powering up the fire flower is a better idea than nerfing the feather. The feather's robust mechanics are what make Mario World what it is. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9614145
if you look at the game files to see how it prioritizes alien missions it's actually quite cute and you can see how the game designers planned everything out. different alien species have different probabilities of doing a particular mission, and different regions get different mission probabilities.

>Europe gets a lot of infiltration missions because it's a major X-COM funding area
>but alien bases are rare there because aliens prefer to put those in more sparsely populated areas
>Southeast Asia gets a lot of abduction missions due to its huge population density
and so forth

>>9605143
Guy who animated porn in Flash, mainly of various cartoons and of some anime during the 2000s and early 2010s. He was very famous on 4chan once upon a time, in part for memery he engaged in and for coming here and interacting with people, making anniversary animations for the site, etc, but in part because he was just REALLY fucking good at animating, even in the late 2000s. He was good at imitating the styles of the works he made porn of, too.

Today, in the 2020s, Flash is a fading memory, and the guy doesn't do all that much of the porn animations anymore, instead doing freelance work animating for various games and other projects (which is the smart thing to do). Zoomers had little to no idea who he was until he did an animation of some characters from Animal Crossing a year or two ago, set to an old Sandy Marton song, and it got memed to hell and back, because zoomers couldn't really handle it.

tl;dr if you're a horndog and you've been a 4chan user for well over a decade, you would probably know who the guy is.

>>9619969
Fair enough. The reason I'm asking is because Acquire (of Way of the Samurai fame, one of my fav games ever, first one that is - the rest are kinda shit if I'm being honest) developed both Tenchu games on the PSX, but then Wrath of Heaven was developed by an entirely different company, FromSoftware, in 2003 and Acquire came up with Shinobido in 2005 instead. I suspected they lost the rights to the original title or something and decided to investigate.

So I went to check what Google has to say about it and Wikipedia presented me with the following:
>Activision purchased the rights to this game from Sony Music Entertainment, who originally published the game in Japan. However, Activision sold the rights to the Japanese game publisher FromSoftware in 2004. FromSoftware's rights agreement does not include games previously published by Activision. FromSoftware licensed distribution of Fatal Shadows to Sega.

The original team behind the games did get hired to work on Shadow Assassins in 2009, but beyond that all the other Tenchu games were made by someone else.

Sooo I'm assuming Shinobido will be better than Wrath of Heaven due to the OG dev team being responsible for it, but I figured I'd ask on 4chan too.

Wanna get my ninja fix on the PS2 and couldn't figure out which game to play.

>It's slow
You have a "give me another row of blocks" button.
It's not as fast as Magical Drop but that's like saying a cheetah isn't as fast as a bullet.
>chaining is too casual
I like the ability to switch blocks mid-chain. It's a lot more active than waiting for your puyo to pop.
>RNG
I can see the issue in this for versus, but I think it's fine for single player.
Frankly if you have another person who regularly likes to play obscure Japanese puzzle games with you you're already winning life so I don't see room for complaint.

A lot of this comes down to taste; IMO Panel de Pon is the best puzzle game ever made but some people are looking for a different experience and there's nothing wrong with that.
Give it a break for a few months and try coming back to it when you're in a different mood, you might be surprised by how much of a difference that makes. I didn't use to like it as much as I do now, it grew on me over time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Flashing bootleg GBA cartridges with a GC to GBA link cable and a PC or softmodded GC or Wii can be accomplished by following the steps below.

Required materials:

- GC to GBA Link Cable
- PC with a serial port
- Softmodded GameCube or Wii
- Flash cartridge
- EZ-Flash IV Flash Kit

Step 1: Connect the GC to GBA link cable to the GBA cartridge, and the GameCube or Wii.

Step 2: Connect the other end of the GC to GBA link cable to the PC with a serial port.

Step 3: Download the EZ-Flash IV Flash Kit from the EZ-Flash website.

Step 4: Install the EZ-Flash IV Flash Kit on the PC.

Step 5: Launch the EZ-Flash IV program, and select the “Flash Cartridge” option.

Step 6: Select the “GC-GBA Link” option, and then choose the “Start” button.

Step 7: On the GC or Wii, press the “Link” button.

Step 8: On the PC, the EZ-Flash IV program will now detect the GBA cartridge, and will begin to flash the cartridge.

Step 9: When the flashing process is complete, press the “Finish” button to exit the EZ-Flash IV program.

Step 10: Disconnect the GC to GBA link cable from the PC, and the GameCube or Wii.

Once these steps have been completed, you will have successfully flashed a bootleg GBA cartridge with a GC to GBA link cable and a PC or softmodded GC or Wii.

>>9615226
>Virtua Fighter 2 was one of the few 3D fighting games you could play on PC actually anon.

Back in the mid 90's Sega worked with a PC publisher called Expert software, and ported many of their Sega Saturn games to Windows 95. There is Virtua Fighter PC, which was a port of the Sega Saturn Virtua Fighter Remix. There is a port of Virtua Fighter 2, which was a direct port of the Saturn game, with some enhancements. There's also a port of Last Bronx for Win95 too, and that was also a port of the Saturn game. The PC ports do contain some extras like hardware acceleration via D3D, and some games contain the arcade meshes and such. Virtua Fighter 2 was ported to the PS2 in Japan, and has a 360 and PSN port. Virtua Fighter 3 is a much more obscure game, because it was only ported to the Dreamcast.

>>9615925
>Tao Feng: Fist of the Lotus (xbox)
Designed by John Tobias after he split with the MK team, it felt dated and cliché in 2003 and somehow makes the PS2 3D mortal kombat games feel polished.
>Star Wars: Masters of Teräs Käsi (ps1)
Clunky, has completely inconsistent mechanics and often bizarre buttons, with some characters having guns and weapons that only just about function. This piece of shit disregards all of the rules and trends of the genre and it shows, but has a based and massive roster if you're a fan of the IP.
>Deadliest Warrior the Game (xbox live arcade, not /vr/ but also not new)
A rare fighter with absolute no recognisable influence from any other well known 3D fighting game. The animations are mostly dogshit, sound is an afterthought, and the UI designers have probably never player anything resembling a fighting game, but it actually plays pretty well if you can free your brain from the shackles of 'real' fighting games.
>Kakuto Chojin (xbox)
Doesn't quite count was developed by a Japanese subsidiary but published by Microsoft for the og xbox but its definitely worth mentioning because its fucking sick, and it feels western. It also came out in North America first by a long time if I remember correctly.

They offer a lot of replayability though, going all the way back to Soul Edge (Soul Blade) and starting with the Edge Master Mode. I've always liked weapons in fighting games, so it's probably my fav series next to SamSho and Last Blade. Just a shame you couldn't destroy the enemy weapons in SoulCalibur and up, it did add an extra layer of strategy - you'd rely on blocking too much, your weapon would eventually break and you'd be at someone's mercy unless you got really lucky with using the martial arts (you could actually punch, kick and throw without the weapon) alone.

Fun fact, the gameplay in Alice 1 is basically a carbon copy of Heavy Metal FAKK2, which engine it reused (McGee was friends with Ritual). All the same parkour moves and everything.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2wnv0pvD-rw

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: bumparino

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9619436
Unironically learn basics of Photoshop from some online tutorials or have someone else do it for you if you can't find quality scans online. I've started writing a post on how to go about it earlier today, but in the end went "fuck it" once I've realized it would take ages to explain in writing, whereas if we'd meet IRL I could probably teach you in like thirty minutes. So yeah anon, download Photoshop, watch some tutorials, fuck around with it. It'll come in handy in life, won't be wasted time. Basic pointers are to use CMYK, start with a large project file (you lose quality when you "zoom in", so it's better to go large initially and then scale down on the image right before sending it to print), use the proper dimensions (can easily find these online) for boxes/labels and whenever you can copy shit from other high quality scans / projects. Say if someone already made a high quality "Nintendo Seal of Quality" vector, just copy that instead of retracing the whole thing on your own, no need to reinvent the wheel.

posts.com:
How to find pinball and pinball tournaments in your area:
US, Canada, Australia, Japan, Finland, UK
https://pinballmap.com/
Worldwide:
https://pinside.com/pinball/map
Europe:
https://findapinball.com/en/browse/

Tournaments:
Depending on where you live, there may be a facebook group for players in your area.
You can also find tournaments near you here and here:
https://www.ifpapinball.com/calendar/
https://matchplay.events/live

Pinball Simulators that will give you a free virtual pin or two as a sample:
Pinball Fx 3 (Sorcerer's Lair, Fish Tales)
Zaccaria (Time Machine)
Pinball Arcade (Varies weekly or something)
There's also Visual Pinball, which is a freeware pinball simulator.

How to become Good at Pinball (wholly optional):
https://www.deadflip.com/tutorials/ (techniques in gif form)
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL-WQLGFMr97DnxeE1Rmi-wAwa-Vm7D-7i

There are many scam pinball retailer websites. See here for more information:
https://pinside.com/pinball/forum/topic/beware-of-scam-game-seller-websites

Discussion topics:
Is Keith Elwin as good as they say?
Is Multimorphic great or not great?
Cool things that can be done now that pinball machines are network connected

>>9608553
GameFreak was incapable of doing it and they want to keep control of the series. GF is basically an indie company that struck it big and barely knew what to do with it. By all means there should've been a console Pokemon RPG; Pokemon fans will defend it not happening but it was a wasted opportunity.
That said, Pokemon hit global saturation really late in the N64 lifespan. It reached America in September 98, but it took until 99 to really explode. By then, Gen II was about to release, Nintendo was busy with Gamecube development, and the 64DD wasted resources and time.
If Pokemon managed to stay as popular in 2001/2002(And yes, I know it was still selling millions of copies, but RS sold a little over half of what RBY did), I think there would've been a bigger push but Colosseum/Gale of Darkness shows they were considering something a bit more intricate.

Game Freak was a company that caught lightning in a bottle and had no idea how to handle it.
After essentially giving control to Nintendo (via the formation of The Pokemon Company) Game Freak changed from an independent gaming company to a branch of a brand management company.

>>9615090
Just get the max pack from gog, its a pre-setup dosbox.
The win95 version is better, but not as stable. I don't think multiplayer is very important for you, so that shouldn't matter.

Carma 2 has some music issues, a basic fix is just renaming carma2_hw.exe to anything else and it should work, but it will crash everytime you quit.
The better solution is downloading _inmm.dll (a program used to get certain older implementations of audio to work), specifically https://community.pcgamingwiki.com/files/file/107-patched-_inmmdll. It contains some extra for variables carma2 (and many other games), install it.
You patch Carma2_hw.exe by just dragging it onto inmmcnf.exe (or its shortcut name _inmm.dll setup).
You then open inmmcnf.exe normally and add *.ogg (that's what the files should be) to the filetypes and set player to DirectShow (same for the default just in case).
You then go to the _inmm.ini tab and add the songs either via the button or dragging them on the list and then saving. You put the .ini it wants to save in the folder with the executable. Don't move the music folder as it points to that.

its always a larger hassle to write out _inmm instructions than actually doing it as its quite simple.

>>9610126
It's mostly likely that a leaked clock capacitor is what caused this. It is a well known issue with the OG Xbox from hardware versions 1.0 through 1.5 - so almost all of them. Only 1.6 are exempt from this problem I believe. Since you meantioned the system clock not working it's pretty much guaranteed that it leaked and ceased to function. The end result of this failure is the acid corroding the circuits underneath or near where the cap is placed on the board, eventually killing the power button. To repair this is beyond my knowledge or capabilities. I can't even tell you whether it's a feasible option or not. This is why every single Xbox out there that's below hardware v1.6 needs to be openend and have it's clock cap removed or better yet, replaced - the system can run without it, as you have seen since yours is dead. RIP your Xbox

>what's so great about the Xbox?
Games just run really good on it even if you booted it up with the original old crusty ass thermal paste. I suppose it's a redundant console if you have the other two, but if you want to play the best version of a lot of games it's gonna be on the Xbox. There was also of course the online which back then was actually worth paying for and had the benefit of making sure every aspect of live was integrated at the core level, but that's not longer a thing today due to obvious reasons. >>9606515
>It's a fuckin hassle with how slow the Xbox receives data
I'm using a SATA drive and I plug my Xbox directly to my computer when I want to transfer games and it works fine, and I use the full size isos not the trimmed down ones that cause glitches. I don't know how you have yours set up exactly but you should trim down as much middleman hardware as possible. Heck you could even take the hard drive out of the xbox and directly transfer the games to it using FATXplorer, then you'll be able to use the full transfer speeds of your drives.

>>9610204
The process to fix it will be:
>remove the capacitor
>clean the board
>repair damaged power button traces

Most of the small components near the capacitor are only essential for the clock circuit, so they won't need to be replaced if they've been melted off the board.

Raphnet adapters are the best and most compatible but value depends on the delivery cost to wherever you live (and Saturn>USB is OOS atm).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For me personally: Ape Escape, Jumping Flash 1 and 2, and Klonoa: Door to Phantomile are all extremely aesthetically pleasing and well thought out. I extend aesthetic to include the way the game presents through audio as well, all those games have such nice color choices, character design and environments alongside music that fits impeccably to the environments.
Klonoa especially has some of my favorite enemy designs ever. There's thid part in the forest world, where you have to walk a full U-Turn path that encircles a massive wooden gear - the first time you pass it, the enemies (iirc) are flying blue Moos - the second pass, once the gear is in motion, instead contains two very alien looking enemies that appear nowhere else in the game. I never knew why they did that when it seemed so arbitrary, but my instincts are they created something cool, wanted it in the game, and put them in just to do it, just for visual variety and to just kinda be noticed. I love things like that.
I guess all 3 games sort of represent that certain type of Japanese aesthetics and design where it captures all the high notes but without it being under the umbrella of anime. I like when games do that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Should also mention Astal and Lomax have beautiful pixel art that still is unparalleled imo, freakishly pretty games. Rayman as well, I feel bad for just now remembering that one.

Sephiroth was already insane, he just found a satisfying rationalisation. >>9599512
After becoming an adult and getting into classical music, the series' growing pretensions from 6 onward make me think they were actually trying to create interactive operas.

Operas often only change scenes at the beginning of a new act. So to tell a complete narrative in 3-5 scenes, exposition dumps are a big part of it. It can sometimes be like an episode of Springer with a dynamic soundtrack that reacts to two characters having an argument over something that happened offscreen and the details slowly emerge as they yell stuff at each other accusingly, for example. If you imagine the flashback scenes as the group talking to one another, and Uematsu's music being written to pull you into caring about the sudden left turn of the narrative, it makes sense.

I'm not saying its brilliant or that there wouldn't be a better way to do it, but as the series got more serious, its pretty obvious that they considered opera an artistic aspiration for the series and now that I'm familiar enough with the tropes of Wagner and Italian Verismo operatic storytelling, the way 6 onwards delivers story beats feels similar to the way Puccini (Aeris' death) or Wagner (giant, world ending sword duel climax) would present them.

>>9599610
Good post. Most FF fans are completely artistically illiterate and can't see any nuance. Sephiroth is shown to be cold and ruthless even when he was a "hero." He was raised to be a killing machine, held up as a figurehead for Shinra's propaganda, showered with praise for slaughtering any perceived enemy, and we learn from Lucretia that he was never even held by his mother as a baby; he was whisked off by scientists to be a research specimen the moment he was born. You don't need to be a psychologist to see how fucked up someone would be from living a life like that. Even before the Nibelheim incident, he was, at best, a functional sociopath with a massive superiority complex, but most players completely miss all of that and take the claim that he's a hero at face value.

I'd also argue that he doesn't actually give a shit about Jenova or the Ancients. Those are just post-hoc rationalizations he uses to justify his desires. When he reads in Gast's research notes that Jenova is an Ancient, he claims that entitles him to take the planet back from the humans who betrayed the Ancients. Later, when he travels through the Lifestream and learns the truth about Jenova (that she was actually just a monster that wiped out the Ancients), he twists it around and says that he's entitled to rule the planet because Jenova was even greater than the Ancients were. In other words, all he really wants is to satisfy his own ego by elevating himself up to godhood compared to the rest of the world, and he'll use whatever excuse he can come up with to justify it.

>>9600431
Its cool being able to understand the references when you notice them. Curtains Down from Blood Money is a lot more satisfying when you understand the context of the scene the target is playing out, for instance.

The opera is called Tosca, and thats the ending scene. There's at least a dozen Kojima-tier absurd plot twists that precede it, but basically the character being executed believes that its a mock execution, because the chief of police pardoned him but had to keep up appearances because he's known for being tough on crime. Usually on stage, that character acts like a chad with no fear of death, and his girlfriend is singing these joking lyrics about what a good actor he is while the music itself is really tense and clues you in that he's actually fucked and the police chief didn't actually give the order to pardon. He gets shot and dies with a look of shock on his face, and his girlfriend jumps off a cliff to avoid arrest, then curtains the end.

So in a meta sense, the two targets are actually playing the roles of the two opera characters, and 47 is actually playing the role of the executioner. Tosca is pretty babbys first opera tier so its not hard to see why it'd be one they'd be looking for level material in, but the way they pulled it off is actually really impressive.

The only reason we even got the NES and SNES Minis is because the Wii U was a massive, massive flop with nothing going for it and Nintendo needed something, anything to fill the void until the Switch came out. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Released 30 years ago
>One of the simplest and most basic copy protections
>STILL filters just about every emulator, clone system, flashcart, and the MiSTer to this day without manual user intervention
>But it would be easy and even cheaper for a bootleg cart to have bypassed it in the day

Is this literally impossible to solve on modern hardware/emulators? The game's copy protection could not possibly be any dead simpler, it just simply writes to SRAM, and then checks if the write was successful. The game had no SRAM so it knows it's not running on an authentic cart if it passes. Ironically all a pirated cart of it would have to do is be too cheap to even include a SRAM chip and it would bypass it, even if you have no knowledge of patching/hacking ROMS, all you would have to do is inflate the ROM size to 4MB with blank filler and then it would work since the Genesis required games to use a more complicated save method if their ROMS were that large, and that's assuming you are not using an emulator that just simply has the option to disable SRAM saves. Nearly every emulator, flashcart, clone system, etc however if it sees a game attempting to save will process the save request and trip the copy protection.

Is there no way for an emulator or flashcart to know that the game is not supposed to have SRAM from headers or any other sort of information without a hard-coded list of what carts had what hardware? If this was effective how come you don't hear of just about any other Genesis game ever doing it? How come SNES emulators don't have this issue when some games on that system also tried this trick?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9620128
>Well yes, I was wondering if it was due to lack of headers. I should have clarified impossible without essentially re-dumping every game in a new format that has headers.
there's two different kinds of headers in this case: headers that are not part of the original data (e.g. iNES-type headers, which has mapper information that the cart doesnt need because it has to do with how the cart is wired), and headers that are part of the original data (like the SNES; despite being called headers, they're actually at the end of bank 0 in every snes rom, and are required to be present)
iNES-like headers are blatantly fucking retarded. I get why they were done at the time, but they're completely nonsensical ultimately. bsnes' manifests are a much better solution overall because something like that actually describes how a cart is wired and doesn't do something retarded like modify the data with otherwise ancillary information (making it a pain to quickly use checksums to verify you have a good dump, especially if one finds said headers are not sufficient to describe everything, which is why, say, iNES2.0 exists)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9620250
>and headers that are part of the original data (like the SNES; despite being called headers, they're actually at the end of bank 0 in every snes rom, and are required to be present)

Oh, I wasn't even aware that the actual games themselves had headers like that. I assumed all ROM formats that had headers were something that was added from the dumping process like iNES headers. That makes the copy protection for SNES games that relied on the SRAM being the correct size a little silly then, with the copiers flat out ignoring that and just giving the games a large chunk of SRAM to use for saves.

>iNES-like headers are blatantly fucking retarded. I get why they were done at the time, but they're completely nonsensical ultimately. bsnes' manifests are a much better solution overall because something like that actually describes how a cart is wired and doesn't do something retarded like modify the data with otherwise ancillary information (making it a pain to quickly use checksums to verify you have a good dump, especially if one finds said headers are not sufficient to describe everything, which is why, say, iNES2.0 exists)

Does bSNES put those manifests in a separate file from the ROM itself? I can see why that would not catch on if you suddenly have several files to deal with for every single SNES game instead of just one, but I do like the header making far more sense. As for the checksum, can't you fix that with only checksumming the data after the header?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9620293
>Does bSNES put those manifests in a separate file from the ROM itself?
If I'm not mistaken, it compiles them into the binary, and uses the sha1sum (i think, could be a different hash algo) to determine which to use, and falls back to some heuristics checks otherwise. You can create a custom manifest file in the same directory as a rom though (but for a matching hash it might be ignored, i don't remember the exact behavior here)
>can't you fix that with only checksumming the data after the header
yeah but thats retarded. then you need to know how big the header is; its a solution that 'works' but just shouldn't be necessary. for the layman its way more of a pain too. i can easily just say `sha1sum smw.smc` and get the proper hash to validate I've got a good dump when looking at a good dump listing (or for wingdings users, some sort of shell addon which isnt too uncommon, i used one of these like a decade ago), but for nes its slightly more annoying, for example something like `tail -c +16 smb3.nes | sha1sum`, which is all fine and dandy but just really silly to even have to worry about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>yeah but thats retarded. then you need to know how big the header is; its a solution that 'works' but just shouldn't be necessary. for the layman its way more of a pain too

Just make it a standard size per-system then, headers usually are anyway. Hard-coding them into the emulator seems wasteful and pointless, and making them a separate file would be a mess. Incorporating them into the actual ROM makes far more sense.

>>9616723
>it improves upon the original in every meaningful way
You are now forced to obtain the sword key as Jill, reducing exploration options.
The keys are now obtained in a set order, meaning that sequence breaking and seeing unique scenes is no longer possible.
Rebecca only appears with Richard, which was a hidden event in the original game.
When fighting against Yawn, in the original 3 events could occur dependent on the choices the player made throughout the game. You either have to get the antidote yourself, play a sequence as the partner character, or are carried by the partner character. Only the first event occurs in the remake due to the complete removal of all choices.
The true opening of the game is changed and made nonsensical. In the original, the player would be left in the main hall after the first encounter with any door to choose from. In the remake, all of the paths are locked or are immediate dead ends, with the only actual path being a linear straight line to get a crossbow, filled with constant tutorializing the original never had (in addition to the remake still having Barry say he'd be searching over there, which he isn't).
All optional rooms from the original are made mandatory with the exception of the aquarium office, but that contains the crest that unlocks the magnum so it is basically not optional.
Getting the crank is turned from a couple seconds of stair pushing to a walk down a straight forest path (which makes no sense as the reason they don't leave the mansion is because of the dogs, and dogs never spawn here). You go through two "puzzles" that essentially solve themselves with how braindead they are, and it concludes with the laughable first Lisa encounter, where she knocks you out and then does... nothing before fighting you when you wake up.
The Guardhouse is turned into a straight line with zero exploration despite that area being the most open to expansions given its size in the original concepts.

The process of getting anything done in Neptune's room is extended to the point of annoyance, turning a relatively short sequence into a several minutes long one of running around in a very dull and very empty environment, complete with a return trip if you want to use the V-Jolt. You also lose the box pushing path for seemingly no reason other than to force the player to use the other door for equally little reason.
The library in the mansion is reduced from 3 rooms, one hidden and one hosting a puzzle, complete with their own files and unique environments, into a more generic library to be a boss arena for a far easier Yawn boss fight. None of the elements of the original library are replicated.

The MO Disk Hunt only starting in the lab reduces any interesting exploration for the player, effectively making them not think about the future by removing any items that will be used in the future.
The lab puzzles are pretty much the same, just with extra steps, while the lab itself has zero expansions whatsoever beyond literal walking towards the end.
The game removes all past unlockables from RE1 and replaces them, meaning no original costumes, weapons, or modes. This means no Battle Game or Advanced Mode.
It sucks.

>>9614845
Adding to the PMD stuff that still counts as retro

Screech is fucked up. It works outside the standard buff/debuff formula, and no amount of Defense Curling will undo a Screech debuff. Having ultra high defense stats and getting hit by merely a single one can make you go from taking 1 damage from weak enemies to over 50. At 2 Screeches, you have roughly 3% of your normal defense stat, a stronger debuff than anything else in the game.
However, if you've got a pokemon that can use it alongside a multihit attack like Fury Swipes, you can combine the two so they come out in the same turn. You can simply delete anything in your path with this combo.

Sonicboom counts as well. Normally it only hits for 20 damage all the time, but for some reason it hits for 55 damage in Rescue Team. It is also a ranged attack and never misses. Simply put, if you have it in a challenge Level 1 dungeon, 99% of the dungeon dies in only 2 uses, and you never have to get close.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
for me it's the Shock Cannon in Ratchet and Clank 3

Outside of being a space shotgun, the weapon's main gimmick is being able to charge up a shot which uses more ammo but does more damage appropriately, but also the charged shot persists as a beam for about a second, which can be swept around to deal damage in a wider area and is good for crowd control.

The "problem" with this weapon lies in the fact that the devs clearly only seriously playtested it using lock strafe controls, which has relatively slow aim and limits how fast you can sweep the Shock Cannon beam to just sweeping it in one direction before it fades. If you instead use the third person controls, which lets you fire weapons in whichever direction Ratchet is facing instead of always toward a screen reticle, and move Ratchet around real fucking fast after firing the charged Shock Cannon, you can whip the beam back and forth and hit the same target like 5-6 times with the same shot and do basically the most damage at once as possible in the game.

Probably my favourite instance of "the starting weapon is the most broken weapon in the game" because of how easily this exploit flies under the radar.

The issue with petrification on weapons in FFX is that you don't get overkills when they trigger, even if you normally were strong enough to.
Overkills double AP, which is a big deal because they double AP for EVERY character with battle participation, not just the one that gets the kill.
Random encounters aren't about survival or attrition. You have Yuna and Rikku, two of the greatest healers in any Final Fantasy game. You aren't going to die.
Random encounters are about squeezing every drop of resources out of your enemies as efficiently as possible like you're a succubus in a level drain doujin.

TLDR; Petrification weapons are a noob trap

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Bambi and Tinker Bell are absolutely ridiculous in Kingdom Hearts.
Bambi constantly refills your mana for the duration he's summoned. There are only two costs for summoning; mana, and not being able to use other party members while the summon is active. Bambi instantly refunds you for the mana you used to summon him so the only cost is losing Donald and Goofy for a while, which is perfectly fine considering you get to spam whatever magic you want all that time.
Tinker Bell is a literal life saver; she constantly heals you and if you die while she's summoned you come back to life at the cost of her being unsummoned, like a Legend of Zelda fairy. That's already great because late game enemies can basically one-shot you on hard mode. What makes her completely nuts is that she doesn't take up a party slot. (You know, because she's small.) So you get to keep Donald and Goofy the whole time she's out. And unlike every other summon in the game she has no timer; she stays summoned until her effect triggers.
Also, she was already the hottest character in Disney and Square gave her pink panties and lipstick for Kingdom Hearts, the fucking chads.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The sight bracelet in the Shiren the Wanderer series. When worn, it let's you see all enemies and items on the map. It effectively removes the exploration of the game and is far in a way the best bracelet in any game it appears in. Some speedrunners and pros ban its use as it's that good. I'd like to give a special mention to the wall clip bracelet. It appears in less Shiren games but when it's there, it becomes a great contender for best bracelet. When worn, the player can pass through walls and will take damage every turn they're in a wall. A small price to pay for invincibility inside walls, effortless traversal, and becoming effectively unbeatable when used with the sight bracelet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9617085
Its fine in the context of its release date but Mario 64 is older and way better. Its a game that needs to be looked at from a 1997 point of view. It still has a lot of 2d platformer elements to it like linearity although you can move freely. Take Mario 64 out of the equation and it looks good with big open levels. Crash was out in 97, but Croc is more open and exploration based. Croc is different enough from Crash and good enough in its own way to be unique and fun in comparison. This isn’t the case when compared with Mario 64. They have a lot in common and Mario beats Crocs ass.

What else was out in 97? Jumping Flash is a somewhat similar game but in first person. Ninpen Manmaru on Saturn is similar in quality. A little less collection and a little more obstacle course. Chameleon Twist on N64 was similar in quality, it had some better bosses but more linear levels. I’d say all four are about even.

Tomb Raider was better but of course its very different. It still blew Croc and most of these others out of the water as a 3d platformer, but its a bit of an apples to oranges comparison. Same applies to Goemon on N64.

I’ve never played Floating Runner, Soultrap or the first N64 Doraemon but they probably suck. Jersey Devil is on my to do list and might be good, idk. Croc shits all over Bubsy. That leaves the Sonic World part of Sonic Jam, which controls better with an analog stick but isnt really much of a game. Let’s say croc is better than all of thesewith JD as a question mark.

That leaves Croc as a middle tier 3d platformer at the time it was released. But this was so early and 3d platformers were so primitive that they hadn’t really all gotten refined gameplay, camera and control wise. Within a few years in the late 90s many 3d platformers that I’d consider better were released on the N64, PS1 and Dreamcast. Croc is one of the best games of its type on the Saturn for what its worth, but thats a system known for having no 3d platformers.

>>9610640
Hi OP, I just played through both of these the past year, so I can give you a fresh and honest opinion.

First, it’s a superior way to play the NES games because you can press a button to save the game, instead of needing to commit suicide or press a button on the second controller. NES games run great, you can move with the joystick.

Ocarina of Time and Master Quest run very well, with the later adding some very challenging content. You can set the C buttons either to X, Y, and Z or use the directions on the C stick. I ended up using the C stick since it was easier to visualize. It was a little weird at first, but after a few hours I was a pro at flinging the stick to use items. Z targeting becomes L targeting which is just as effective. I really enjoyed playing these with the GC controller. As for the content, it has dome minor changes like the fire temple music, mirror shield, etc.

Unfortunately, what people are saying about Majora’s Mask emulation is true. I had a lot of problems with slowdown, it got pretty sluggish at time, and it crashed once while I was halfway through the (very, very tedious) beaver race quest. I didn’t have any audio issues, I was playing with rumble off. I still managed to beat the game without dying and still had a lot of fun with it.

;tldr, they’re great and worth getting if the price is right

>Japanese/USA 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 N64 releases are alternatively known as NTSC 1.0, NTSC 1.1, and NTSC 1.2 respectively. >>9594662
It has to do with the speed of the combat and how mobile the character is.

In something like Bayo or Ninja Gaiden you're so much more faster and agile that it wouldn't feel well. Zelda games and Maximo are much slower in combat and you move a lot less. There are sometimes inputs that use the 360 but between 2 different attack buttons, fast enough frame data to make use of pauses (eg A,A vs A,wait,A), and the many ways you can dial up an attack there is no reason to resort to these inputs which as I said are going to feel bad with how fast and agile these newer characters are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
N64 was the "tech demo" phase for a lot of this stuff. Really showing up all of the different ways a character can control in a 3D space, and all of the different things you can do with an analogue stick in gameplay.

After that, we move into the stream-lining phase, where developers are thinking less about what the player "could" do, and thinking more about what most players are going to want, which is simplicity of controls and mechanics. That's either a good or a bad thing, depending on how you view it.

Seems like it was very common for an N64 game to have different movement speeds, climbing, swimming, crawling, ledge grappling, first person view modes, and flight all baked into the design, while a modern game like Elden Ring might not necessarily have even half of those options.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9594662
more options doesn't necessarily mean better. OoT was a very good start on 3D combat but right now I would say there are two game series that influence 3D action games the most: Devil May Cry and Dark Souls not retro though.

The prior focuses on giving the player as many combat options as possible and makes that the fun of the game. Launchers, flying attacks, guns, ways to combo enemies, parries, everything you could want to do. These games are more about being stylish than just outright winning the fight. However this limits the enemy design as these games can quickly become unfun if there's too many enemies you can't combo effectively, or if the bosses act in a way that's too limiting to your arsenal.

While the latter is the exact opposite, you have an extremely narrow set of options in combat. Block, dodge, light swing, heavy swing, shoot projectile and maybe a few more options. While this seems limiting it allows the developers to focus much more heavily on challenging enemy design based on how enemies respond and require you to use the few options in your arsenal. People generally love boss fights in these kind of games for this exact reason, every single boss is like learning a song in a rhythm game since its mostly been simplified to "when do I dodge and when do I hit?".

OoT has a lot of options that lack purpose. Yes you can angle your swipes, horizontally or vertically, but what value does that have over just hitting the B button? The answer is none because enemies don't respond to things in ways that warrant you to change that. Would crouch stabbing have any value if it wasn't just objectively the best DPS in the game? I don't think so, because no enemies have a mechanic where you need to crouch to evade their attacks. Dodge mechanics are hardly even necessary because only a tiny few enemies can threaten your shield, I can't even think of any other than Darknuts.

So I think that answers your question, quality > quantity.

The Saturn version of DOA is superior to the PS1 version, this is not debatable.

The Dreamcast version of DOA 2 is superior to the PS2 version, but that's mainly because the publisher tricked the dev team into releasing an in-progress build before it was done. It might have looked a lot better if it had been given a little more time in the oven.

>>9616005
The PS2 only having 4MB of VRAM and no hardware AA really hurt it in the beginning. Devs were able to work around this over time and get some very impressive results from the hardware, but some of the early PS2 versions of games that also released on the Dreamcast were pretty rough in comparison.

It's funny though, because the same thing happened with the PS3, only it was due to Cell being new and the hard 256MB RAM/256MB VRAM limits that the console had, as opposed to the unified 512MB of RAM that the 360 had.

We used to see pretty big differences between different versions of a console game, there were usually pros and cons for each one. There are a lot of /vr/ multiplats where you can tell which version you're looking at just by a single screenshot. Nowadays we just get the PS/XB versions that are basically identical, and then a Switch version that looks like shit.

Lurk more zoomer, The Saturn was the lead platform and that version was on store shelves before the PS1 port was. The PS1 version sacrificed draw distance for framerate, so while the game runs better you can't see the other side of the room you are in.

Door animations take longer, but that's only an issue if you're an ADHD addled zoombrain who can't sit still, or you're speedrunning.

> SotN
You got me here, the Saturn port was pretty rough. Konami decided to make it a "budget release", and dumped it on a b-team that had zero experience developing for the Saturn and also saddled them with an extremely tight deadline. As a result they made a bunch of full retard decisions and rushed everything so performance suffered. The team was so butthurt they actually added whiny messages as comments in the game's code.

The recently completed English fan translation is worth checking out if you have a Saturn though, it fixes many of the performance issues, adds qol improvements (especially with the map), and while the Saturn exclusive areas are hit and miss they're fun to check out if you are a Castlevania fan. The biggest reason to play SotN on the Saturn is being able to play it with a d-pad that doesn't suck complete shit like the PS1's and Xbox 360's.

Here's a protip for the future - if you want to shittalk the Saturn and look like you might actually know what you are talking about (instead of being a mouthbreathing retard) mention the Doom port.

>>9619384
HRAPs came in generic, SA, and SE until the Vewlix layouts when the SA became the standard model and thus began to massively outnumber the limited edition SEs. That itself was just following the market trend enforced by SFIV being a Taito X2/Vewlix game and Capcom insisting the officially licensed MadCatz sticks match the arcade panel. More or less the reason the TE is so over square is because it was originally designed for a Noir layout. I -guess- it's that way initially because Vewlix cabs could be used for Lindbergh as well as the Taito Type X family, and not just the Sega cabinets, but that still leaves VF5 as basically the only 3D fighter on that platform.

Seimitsu was until very recently one of those super old fashioned Japanese companies with a basic ass 90s website with a traditional order form that didn't make a lot of effort to sell to the home market in general too though.

>>9620063

Perception that the Japanese joysticks are the official control method for many retro arcade games. Which is mostly accurate, although using a JLF to play SF2 isn't quite as period accurate as some might think it is.

A well-broken-in 90s LS-32 has a very rounded off gate and more deflection than a fresh JLF or a new-model LS-32. In certain ways the old American "super" joystick (also known as the iL compact joystick) resembles an old LS-32 more than a present day JLF does.

>back weapons
Are you using a quad or a tank? If you're a biped they're generally a bad idea due to the kneeling mechanic, you'd be better off with some missiles.
>beam rifle
If you mean laser rifles, these are generally good generalist weapons. Keep it, get the optional parts that increase EN output and EN weapon damage/firerate/EN usage. If using it makes you run out of energy consider ditching it for something ballistic though.
>dumbfire rockets
You can try but they're generally hard to aim, you're better off with missiles at this stage.
>I haven't FELT slow.
If you can't dictate the engagement distance in AC, you're going slow. At that point you need to rely on superior defense or damage to make up for it. The back weapon is probably the reason for it, you're using a good chunk of weight that could go towards better guns or armor for something absurdly situational. Or you could ditch that dead weight to go faster.
If you want to go full unga-bunga get some arm bazookas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've done a bunch of mods. Here's a brief list:
Famicom composite (worthless*)
Mega drive 60Hz (worthless*)
Gameboy backlight/bivert (mediocre, lots of ghosting, angles are fucky)
GBA chink AGS-101 swap (great to look at, but holding a GBA isn't comfortable as an adult)
PS1 modchip (worthless*)
Dreamcast GD-emu, fan swap (great, although the fan swap needed some extra work)
N64 RGB mod (great)
Xbox 128mb swap (worthless, I wanted to play VC3 but there's no good way to get a lightgun working on it)
Switch joycon d-pad shell (inferior shiny plastic, but having a d-pad is too important. I use them in the grip anyway, so you barely notice it)

Softmods:
PS2 freeMCboot, HDD>SD adapter (great)
Xbox softmod (great)
Wii softmod (great)

All the worthless* are for mods that were superseded by MiSTer, at the time they were okay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9615008
I'd recommend just grabbing some old electronic devices you don't care about anymore and going wild on these. Also good luck, it's really hard the first time around, gets progressively easier with time, but yeah... Don't tackle any projects until you're ready. First time I've soldered was when I was trying to install a new speaker on the GameBoy Pocket, didn't realise how fast the soldering iron heats up. Looked away for a few seconds (think the cat was doing something stupid) and I ended up burning the fuck out of the PCB. Derp.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9615008
Buy a soldering iron (ideally one with temp control), buy one of those little copper wire cleaning balls, buy some solder. You're done, now go try and solder shit to and from random old crap you have lying around until you get the idea.

Soldering is easy as shit. Soldering neatly? That's a different story, but you can get away with fairly ugly joints no problem, just give them a bit of a tug to check.

posts.com:

>>9616652
Is there any chance that you're using a microSDHC card with an old microSD to SD adapter? I have quite a few of these around the house and some of them simply refuse to work with the faster/newer microSDHC cards. Worst case scenario, you could consider using a small form factor USB drive, like proper tiny one that won't stick out of the PS2 and booting games through OPL straght from that. Them tiny USB sticks come in really large sizes (capacity-wise I mean) nowadays, they cost next to nothing and you really don't have to worry about read and write speeds, because the PS2 won't get faster than 1mb/s, which is still faster than using discs.
